CODE OF ORDINANCES CITY OF MARSHALL, MISSOURI 
____________ 
CONTAINING 
THE GENERAL ORDINANCES 
OF THE CITY 
____________ 
Published in 1984 by Order of the City Council 

PREFACE 
    This Code constitutes a complete recodification of the ordinances of the City of Marshall of a general and permanent nature. 
    Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were the 1967 Code as supplemented through November 5, 1979, and ordinances subsequently adopted by the council. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the Comparative Tables appearing in the back of this volume, the reader can locate any section of the 1967 Code and any subsequent ordinance included herein. 
    The chapters of the Code are arranged in alphabetical order and the sections within each chapter are catchlined to facilitate usage. Footnotes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant provisions of the state law have been included. A table listing the state law citations setting forth their location within the Code is included at the back of this volume. The source of each section is indicated by the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the Comparative Table, also appearing in the back of the volume, any ordinance included herein can be readily found in the Code. 
Numbering System 
    The numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and municipal codes. Each section number consists of two component parts separated by a dash, the figure before the dash representing the chapter number and the figure after the dash indicating the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the first section of Chapter 1 is numbered 1-1 and the third section of Chapter 4 is 4-3. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter and, at the same time, new sections or even whole chapters can be inserted in their proper places simply, by using the decimal system for amendments. By way of illustration: If new material consisting of three sections that would logically come between Sections 4-2 and 4-3 is desired to be added, such new sections would be numbered 4-2.1, 4-2.2 and 4-2.3 respectively. New chapters may be included in the same manner. If the new material is to be included between Chapters 12 and 13, it will be designated as Chapter 12.5. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject, the next successive number being assigned to the article or division. 
Index 
    The index has been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of the headings being couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by municipal officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the index itself which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which he is interested. 
Looseleaf Supplements 
    A special feature of this Code is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental service, by which the Code will be kept up-to-date periodically. Upon the final passage of amendatory ordinances, they will be properly edited and the page or pages affected will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of the Code with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. 
    The successful maintenance of this Code up-to-date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the volume. As revised sheets are received it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publishers that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. 
Acknowledgments 
    The publication of this Code was under direct supervision of George R. Langford, President, and Bill Carroll, Supervising Editor, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. 
    The publishers are most grateful to Mr. Donald Stouffer, City Counselor and Mrs. Dorothy Hughes, City Clerk, for their cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this Code. It is hoped that their efforts and those of the publishers have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of the city readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the city's affairs. 
MUNICIPAL CODE CORPORATION
Tallahassee, Florida 
ORDINANCE NO. 6057 
An Ordinance Adopting and Enacting a New Code of Ordinances for the City of Marshall; Establishing the Same; Providing for the Repeal of Certain Ordinances Not Included Therein; Providing for the Manner of Amending Such Code; and Providing When Such Code and This Ordinance Shall Become Effective. 
    Be It Ordained by the Council of the City of Marshall, Missouri, as follows: 
    Section 1. The Code of Ordinances, consisting of Chapters 1 to 32, each inclusive, is hereby adopted and enacted as the "Code of Ordinances, City of Marshall, Missouri" which Code shall supersede all general and permanent ordinances of the city adopted on or before September 6, 1983, to the extent provided in section 2 hereof. 
    Section 2. All provisions of such Code shall be in full force and effect from and after February 4, 1985, and all conflicting provisions of ordinances of a general and permanent nature enacted on final passage on or before September 6, 1983, and not included in such Code or recognized and continued in force by reference therein are hereby repealed from and after the effective date of such Code. 
    Section 3. The repeal provided for in section 2 hereof shall not be construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a subsequent ordinance which is repealed by this ordinance. 
    Section 4. Any person convicted of a violation of such Code shall be punished as prescribed in section 1-10 thereof, or as provided in any other applicable section of such Code. 
    Section 5. Any and all additions and amendments to such Code, when passed in such form as to indicate the intention of the city to make the same a part of such Code, shall be deemed to be incorporated in such Code, so that reference to such Code shall be understood and intended to include such additions and amendments. 
    Section 6. In case of the amendment of any section of such Code for which a penalty is not provided, the general penalty as provided in section 1-10 of such Code shall apply to the section as amended, or in case such amendment contains provisions for which a penalty, other than the aforementioned general penalty, is provided in another section in the same chapter, the penalty so provided in such other section shall be held to relate to the section so amended, unless such penalty is specifically repealed therein. 
    Section 7. Any ordinance adopted after September 6, 1983, which amends or refers to ordinances which have been codified in such Code, shall be construed as if they amend or refer to like provisions of such Code. 
    Section 8. All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are, to the extent of such conflict, hereby repealed. 
    Sections 9-24. 
Editor's note- Sections 9-24 of this ordinance amend, add or repeal the following Code sections: §§ 2-1, 2-51, 2-85(16), 2-86, 2-87, 2-100(2), 2-101, 2-349, 4-66(5), 11-6, 11-7, 17-1(2), 18-86, 22-33, 31-6(5), 28-1-28-3 and 31-50-31-58, to which the interested user should turn, inasmuch as §§ 9-24 of this ordinance have not been set out herein due to their length. See also the Code Comparative Table at the end of this volume for the complete disposition of this ordinance. 
    Section 25. The City of Marshall has heretofore provided for the assessment of taxes by the county assessor and, as of April 15, 1985, for the collection of city taxes by the county collector. The collection and assessment of taxes for the City of Marshall, by the county collector and the county assessor, shall be as provided by the Revised Statutes of Missouri. Nothing contained herein which operates to repeal any ordinance relating to the performance of the duties by the city collector shall become effective until April 15, 1985. 
    Section 26. This ordinance and the Code adopted hereby, shall become effective February 4, 1985. 
    Passed by the Council of the City of Marshall, Missouri, this 4th day of February, 1985. 
/s/Shirley J. Martin
President
    Approved by the Mayor this 4th day of February, 1985. 
SEAL 
/s/Shirley J. Martin
Mayor
    Filed this 4th day of February, 1985.

  City Clerk 
Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1. - How code designated and cited. 
    The ordinances embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated the "Code of Ordinances, City of Marshall, Missouri," and may be so cited. 
(Code 1967, § 1-1)
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction.[1] 
    In the construction of this Code, and of all ordinances, the following rules shall be observed, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the council: 
    City; corporation. Whenever the words "the city," "this city," "the corporation" or "this corporation" are used they shall be construed as if the words "of Marshall, Missouri" followed them. 
    Computation of time. Whenever a notice is required to be given or an act to be done, a certain length of time before any proceeding shall be had, the day on which such notice is given, or such act is done, shall not be counted in computing the time, but the day on which such proceeding is to be had shall be counted. If the last day is Sunday it shall be excluded. 
State Law reference- Similar construction, RSMo 1.040. 
    Corporate limits, corporation limits. Whenever the words "corporate limits," "corporation limits" or "city limits" are used they shall mean the legal boundary of the City of Marshall. 
    Council. Whenever the word "council" is used, it shall be construed to mean the council of the City of Marshall. 
    Councilman. The word "councilman" shall mean any person elected to that office and shall include those persons who hold other offices and who are ex officio. 
    County. The words "the county" or "this county" shall mean the County of Saline in the State of Missouri. 
    Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision appears requiring the head of a department of the city to do some act or make certain inspections it is to be construed to authorize the head of the department to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the required act or make the required inspection unless the terms of the provision or section designate otherwise. 
    Gender. A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well as to males. 
State Law reference- Similar construction, RSMo 1.030. 
    Interpretation. In the interpretation and application of any provision of this Code, it shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. Where any provision of the Code imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than the general provision imposed by the Code, the provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be deemed to be controlling. 
    Joint authority. All words giving a joint authority to three (3) or more persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such, persons or officers. 
State Law reference- 
Similar construction, RSMo 1.050. 
    Keeper and proprietor. The words "keeper" and "proprietor" shall mean and include persons, firms; associations, corporations, clubs and partnerships, whether acting by themselves or through a servant, agent or employee. 
    Mayor. Whenever the word "mayor" is used it shall mean the mayor of the City of Marshall. 
    Month. The word "month" shall mean a calendar month. 
    Name of officer. Whenever the name of an officer is given it shall be construed as though the words "of the City of Marshall" were added. 
    Nontechnical and technical words. Words and phrases shall be construed according to the common and approved usage of the language; but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in law shall be construed and understood according to such meaning. 
    Number. A word importing the singular number only may extend and be applied to several persons and things as well as to one person and thing. 
State Law reference- Similar construction, RSMo 1.030. 
    Oath. The word "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed." 
    Or, and "Or" may be read "and," and "and" may be read "or" if the sense requires it. 
    Owner. The word "owner," applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant, or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or of a part of such building or land. 
    Person. The word "person" shall extend and be applied to associations, clubs, societies, firms, partnerships and bodies politic and corporate as well as to individuals. 
    Personal property. The term "personal property" includes every species of property except real property, as herein described. 
    Preceding, following. The words "preceding" and "following" mean next before and next after, respectively. 
State Law reference- Similar definition, RSMo 1.020(10). 
    Premises. Whenever the word "premises" is used it shall mean place or places. 
    Property. The word "property" shall include real and personal property. 
State Law reference- Similar definition, RSMo 1.020(11). 
    Public place. The term "public place" shall mean any park, cemetery, school yard or open space adjacent thereto, and all beaches, canals or other waterways. 
    Real property. The term "real property" shall include lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
State Law reference- Similar definition, RSMo 1.020(12). 
    Residence. The term "residence" shall be construed to mean the place adopted by a person as his place of habitation, and to which, whenever he is absent, he has the intention of returning. When a person eats at one place and sleeps at another, the place where such person sleeps shall be deemed his residence. 
    Seal. Whenever the word "seal" is used it shall mean the city or corporate seal. 
    Sidewalk. The word "sidewalk" shall mean any portion of a street between the curbline and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians, excluding parkways. 
    Signature or subscription. The "signature" or "subscription" of a person shall include a mark when the person cannot write. 
    State. The words "the state" shall be construed to mean the State of Missouri. 
    Street. The word "street" shall be construed to embrace streets, avenues, boulevards, roads, alleys, lanes, viaducts and all other public highways in the city. 
    Tenant, occupant. The words "tenant" or "occupant," applied to a building or land, shall include any person holding a written or oral lease or who occupies the whole or a part of such buildings or lands, either alone or with others. 
    Time. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. 
    Week. The word "week" shall be construed to mean seven (7) days. 
    Written, in writing. The words "written" or "in writing" shall be construed to include any representation of words, letters or figures, whether by printing or otherwise. 
State Law reference- Similar definition, RSMo 1.020(17). 
    Year. The word "year" shall mean a calendar year. 
(Code 1967, § 1-2)
State Law reference- Similar definition, RSMo 1.020(6). 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Definitions, rules of construction, etc., RSMo 1.020 et seq.

Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections; other headings. 
    The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, or as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. Chapter, article and division headings shall be treated in the same manner. 
(Code 1967, § 1-3)
Sec. 1-4. - History notes and references. 
    The history notes appearing in parentheses following most sections, and the references and notes appearing in 8-point type throughout the Code, are inserted to assist the user of the Code and shall carry no legal import. 
Sec. 1-5. - Certain ordinances not affected by code. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect the following when not inconsistent with this Code: 
(1)	Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness, or any contract or obligation assumed by the city; 
(2)	The administrative ordinances of the city;
(3)	Any ordinance fixing salaries of officers or employees of the city;
(4)	Any appropriation ordinance;
(5)	Any right or franchise granted by the city council of the city to any person;
(6)	Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, closing, paving, widening, vacating, etc., any street or public way in the city; 
(7)	Any ordinance establishing and prescribing the street grades of any street in the city; 
(8)	Any ordinance providing for local improvements or assessing taxes therefor;
(9)	Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the city, or providing regulations for the same; 
(10)	Any ordinance annexing property to the city;
(11)	Any zoning ordinance;
(12)	Any ordinance prescribing traffic regulations for specific locations, such as but not limited to: Prescribing through streets, parking limitations, parking prohibitions, one-way traffic, limitations on loads of vehicles or loading zones; 
(13)	Any ordinance fixing utility rates and charges;
nor shall such repeal be construed to revive any ordinance or part of an ordinance which is repealed by this Code. 
(Ord. No. 4583, § 3, 2-6-67)
Sec. 1-6. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
(a)	The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinances in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect. 
(b)	The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed or cause of action arising under the ordinance repealed. 
(Code 1967, § 1-4)
Sec. 1-7. - Amendments to Code. 
(a)	All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code of Ordinances, which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code of Ordinances, may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion therein, or in the case of repealed chapters, sections and subsections or any part thereof, by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages affected thereby and the subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed or omitted, in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time that this Code of Ordinances and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code of Ordinances by the council. 
(b)	Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code should be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section of this Code in substantially the following language: "That section ____________ of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Marshall, Missouri, is hereby amended to read as follows: ____________(Set out new provisions in full) ____________" 
(c)	When the council desires to enact an ordinance of a general and permanent nature on a subject not heretofore existing in the Code, which the council desires to incorporate into the Code, a section in substantially the following language shall be made a part of the ordinance: "Section ... It is the intention of the governing body, and it is hereby ordained that the provisions of this ordinance shall become and be made a part of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Marshall, Missouri, and the sections of this ordinance may be renumbered to accomplish such intention." 
(d)	All sections, articles, chapters or provisions of this code desired to be repealed should be specifically repealed by section number or chapter number, as the case may be. 
(Code 1967, § 1-6)
Sec. 1-8. - Altering Code. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to change or amend by additions or deletions, any part or portion of this Code, or to insert or delete pages, or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the city to be misrepresented thereby. 
(Code 1967, § 1-7)
State Law reference- Tampering with a public record, RSMo 575.210. 
Sec. 1-9. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    The sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of a court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code. 
(Code 1967, § 1-5)
Sec. 1-10. - General penalty; continuing violations. 
(a)	Whenever in this Code or in any ordinance or resolution of the city any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or whenever in such Code, ordinance or resolution the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such provision of this Code or any ordinance or resolution shall constitute disorderly conduct and shall be punished by a fine of not less than one dollar ($1.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment not exceeding three (3) months or both, as may be just for any offense, recoverable with costs of suit, together with judgment of imprisonment, until the fine and costs are paid or satisfied; and any person committed for the nonpayment of fine and costs, or either, may be compelled to work out the same as herein provided; but, in any case wherein the penalty for an offense is fixed by any statute, the same penalty shall be used for the punishment of such offense, except that imprisonments when made under city ordinances, may be in the city jail or workhouse instead of the county jail. 
(b)	Each day any violation of any provision of this code or of any such ordinance or resolution shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(c)	In addition to the penalty hereinabove provided, any condition caused or permitted to exist in violation of any of the provisions of this code or any such ordinance or resolution shall be deemed a public nuisance and may be, by the city, abated as provided, by law, and each day that such condition continues shall be regarded as a new and separate offense. 
(Code 1967, § 1-8)
State Law reference- Limitation upon penalty, RSMo 77.590. 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Departments of city government designated. 
    For the purpose of properly conducting the government of the city, the council hereby creates the departments of police, fire, emergency management, inspection, city clerk, finance, municipal services, band and airport. 
(Code 1967, § 2-5; Ord. No. 5947, § 3, 2-21-84; Ord. No. 6047, § 3, 12-17-84; Ord. No. 6676, § 1, 2-1-93) 
Sec. 2-2. - Removal of documents from city clerk's office. 
    No member of the council or other person shall take any paper or document from the clerk's office without leave, and all papers and documents withdrawn therefrom with leave, shall be returned by the person withdrawing the same uninjured and not defaced. All papers and documents delivered to a committee of council or officer by the clerk for the purpose of reporting thereon, shall be returned by the committee or officer at the time of making report. 
(Code 1967, § 2-3)
Secs. 2-3-2-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MAYOR AND CITY COUNCIL[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to compel attendance of witnesses, production of papers, RSMo § 77.100; semiannual statements, RSMo 77.110; powers and duties of mayor and council generally, RSMo 77.260; city council to approve appointments by mayor, RSMo 77.330; removal of elective appointive officers, RSMo 77.340; authority to fix compensation of officers and employees, RSMo 77.440; prohibited financial interests of city officers, RSMo 77.470.

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-16. - Membership of council; election by wards. 
    Until otherwise provided by ordinance, the city council shall consist of eight (8) members, two (2) of whom shall be chosen from each ward of the city in accordance with the provisions of the laws of the state governing cities of the third class. 
(Code 1967, §§ 2-23, 11-6)
State Law reference- Councilmen to be elected by wards, annually and in alternate years, RSMo 77.030. 
Sec. 2-17. - Qualifications of councilmen. 
    No person shall be councilman unless he is at least twenty-one (21) years of age prior to taking office, a citizen of the United States, and an inhabitant of the city for one year next preceding his election, and a resident of the ward from which he is elected six (6) months next preceding his election. 
(Code 1967, § 11-7)
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 77.060. 
Sec. 2-18. - Effect of removal from ward. 
    Whenever a councilman removes from the ward in which he is councilman, such office shall thereby become vacant and the council shall so declare of record. 
(Code 1967, § 2-24)
Sec. 2-19. - Oath of office. 
    Before entering upon the duties of their office, each councilman shall take and subscribe an oath or affirmation before some court of record in the county, or the city clerk or municipal judge, that he possesses all the qualifications prescribed for his office by law, that he will support the Constitution of the United States, and of the State of Missouri, the provisions of all laws of this state affecting cities of the third class and the ordinances of the city, and faithfully demean himself in office. 
(Code 1967, § 2-25)
State Law reference- Oath of office of councilman, RSMo 77.390. 
Sec. 2-20. - Compensation. 
    Each member of the council shall receive as compensation for his services such sum as shall be provided by resolution or ordinance. 
(Code 1967, § 2-26)
Sec. 2-21. - Resignation from office. 
    Resignations of councilmen shall be in writing and addressed to the president of the council. 
(Code 1967, § 2-27)
Secs. 2-22-2-25. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MEETINGS 

Sec. 2-26. - Meetings generally. 
    All meetings of the city council shall be held at such times as the city council may prescribe by resolution. Adjourned meetings shall be held whenever the council shall deem it necessary. 
(Code 1967, § 2-28)
Sec. 2-27. - Special meetings; notice; conduct of business. 
    The mayor, or person acting as mayor, or any three (3) members of the city council, shall have the power and are hereby authorized to call a special meeting of the city council, by serving a notice in writing on each member of the council and the mayor, or person acting as mayor, by delivering to each of them a copy of such notice, or by leaving such copy at his usual place of abode with some inhabitant thereof over the age of fifteen (15) years; and such notice shall state the object of such meeting and the time for holding the same, and such notice shall be written out at length and copied upon the journal of the council proceedings; provided that no business other than that specified in such written notice shall be transacted at such special meeting. 
(Code 1967, § 2-29)
Sec. 2-28. - Duty to attend meetings. 
    No member of the city council shall absent himself from any regular meeting thereof, nor from any adjourned or special meeting after due notice thereof, unless he has leave, or is sick and unable to attend, or is otherwise prevented by circumstances beyond his control; and any member absenting himself without having such excuse, shall be fined not less than one dollar ($1.00) nor more than five dollars ($5.00) unless such fine be remitted by a two-thirds majority of the members elected to the council. 
(Code 1967, § 2-30)
Sec. 2-29. - Chief of police as ex officio sergeant-at-arms. 
    The chief of police shall be ex officio sergeant-at-arms of the city council and shall attend its meetings and execute all its orders. 
(Code 1967, § 2-31)
Sec. 2-30. - Quorum prescribed; authority in absence of quorum. 
    A majority of the members elected to the council shall constitute a quorum to do business, but any two (2) members, including the mayor, may have a roll call of the council, send for and compel the attendance of absent members, and make an order for their censure or fine. 
(Code 1967, § 2-32)
Sec. 2-31. - Order of business at regular meetings. 
    The city council shall prescribe by resolution its own rules of procedure for conducting its business at its regular meetings. 
(Code 1967, § 2-33)
Sec. 2-32. - Order of business at special meetings. 
    The business of special meetings shall be disposed of in the following order: 
(1)	Message or statement from the president of the council as to the cause of convening the council in special sessions. 
(2)	Consideration and disposition of the business mentioned in the president's message or statement. 
(Code 1967, § 2-34)
Sec. 2-33. - Application of Robert's Rules of Order. 
    In the event a matter should arise during a regular or special meeting of the city council, to which the rules of procedure of the city council do not apply, then the rules of procedure outlined in Robert's Rules of Order governing parliamentary procedure, insofar as the same are applicable, shall control. 
(Code 1967, § 2-35)
Sec. 2-34. - Duty of mayor to sign commissions, appointments, approve bonds; execution, record of warrants. 
    The mayor shall sign the commissions and appointments of all officers elected or appointed in the city, and approve all official bonds. He shall sign all licenses issued and warrants drawn upon the city treasury for money and cause the city clerk to attest the same, and affix thereto the seal of the city to keep proper record thereof in books to be provided for that purpose. 
(Code 1967, § 2-9)
State Law reference- Provisions as to mayor of third class city, RSMo 77.230 et seq.; mayor to sign commissions, appointments, approve official bonds, RSMo 77.320. 
Secs. 2-35-2-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - LEGISLATION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Enactment of ordinance generally, RSMo 77.080; approval of mayor, veto, becoming law without signature of mayor, RSMo 77.270.

Sec. 2-41. - Title of bill. 
    The title of every bill shall indicate the purposes or objects sought to be accomplished thereby. 
(Code 1967, § 2-2)
Sec. 2-42. - Procedure for enactment of ordinances. 
    All bills proposed as ordinances shall have their separate readings: 
(1)	The first reading, by title or in full, at which time amendments may be presented and discussion may be had; and 
(2)	The second reading, at which time the names of the members voting for and against the same shall be entered on the journal. 
(Code 1967, § 2-1; Ord. No. 6360, § 1, 10-17-88; Ord. No. 6676, § 2, 2-1-93)
Sec. 2-43. - Effective date of ordinances. 
    All ordinances shall take effect upon their adoption unless an ordinance shall otherwise specify the time when it shall go into effect. 
(Code 1967, § 1-11)
Sec. 2-44. - Recording by city clerk; certificate of publication. 
    All ordinances passed by the council shall be recorded by the city clerk in a proper book or books, with indexes. The originals shall be filed in the city clerk's office; and due proof of the publication of all ordinances requiring publication, by the certificate of the publisher or printer, shall be procured by the clerk, and attached thereto, or written and attested upon the face of the record of such ordinance. 
(Code 1967, § 1-10)
Secs. 2-45-2-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - COMMITTEES 

Sec. 2-51. - Designation of committees to administer business of departments. 
    At the first regular meeting of the city council in May of each year, or as soon thereafter as practicable, the mayor shall appoint the following committees to administer the business of the departments created in section 2-1: municipal services and personnel; property, finance, budget and audit; community development and code; and public relations and public safety. The mayor shall name and designate the chairman of each committee, and prescribe the duties thereof. 
(Code 1967, § 2-6; Ord. No. 5685, § 1, 4-20-81; Ord. No. 5947, § 4, 2-21-84; Ord. No. 6057, § 9, 2-4-85; Ord. No. 6676, § 3, 2-1-93; Ord. No. 6897, § 1, 8-7-95; Ord. No. 7672, § 1, 2-6-06) 
Sec. 2-52. - Duties, meetings. 
    The committees designated in section 2-51 shall meet at such times and perform such duties as the mayor shall prescribe. 
(Code 1967, § 2-7)
Sec. 2-53. - Mayor as ex officio member of committees. 
    The mayor of the city shall be an ex officio member of each cominittee of the city government and while serving therewith shall be chairman thereof. 
(Code 1967, § 2-8)
Secs. 2-54-2-60. - Reserved.

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-61-2-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - REMOVAL OF ELECTIVE OFFICERS FROM OFFICE[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to impeach elective officers, RSMo 77.340; removal and impeachment of municipal officers, RSMo 106.220 et seq.

Sec. 2-66. - Grounds for removal from office. 
    An elective officer of the city may be removed from office for any one of the following causes: 
(1)	Wilfull violation of any of his official duties;
(2)	Culpable official negligence or dereliction of official duty;
(3)	Any conduct inconsistent with his official character and duty;
(4)	Official incompetency;
(5)	Intoxicated while in the performance of any official act or duty, or shall become so intoxicated as to be incapacitated to perform any official act or duty at the time or in the manner required by law. 
(Code 1967, §§ 21-5, 21-18)
Sec. 2-67. - Institution of impeachment proceedings. 
(a)	Preparation of charges, notice. The mayor, or any member of the council may prefer charges against any elective officer by filing with the city clerk a written statement of the charges together with a notice directed to the accused, apprising him of the nature of the charges, and of the time when the accusation will be heard by the council setting as a court of impeachment; whereupon the city clerk shall file the same and cause a copy thereof to be served upon the accused at least five (5) days before the date set for the hearing. 
(b)	Service of notice. Such notice shall be served by any regular policeman of the city, provided, that if for any reason such notice cannot be personally served within the limits of the city, service may be had by posting not less than three (3) copies thereof in as many public places in the city. 
(c)	Return of service. Such notice and charges, with the return of service thereof, shall be laid by the city clerk before the council at its next meeting. 
(Code 1967, § 21-19)
Sec. 2-68. - City council to hear evidence. 
    At the time set for the hearing provided for herein, if due notice has been given the accused, the council shall meet and proceed to hear evidence against and in favor of the accused, and may adjourn from time to time, if necessary, until all the evidence is heard. 
(Code 1967, § 21-20)
Sec. 2-69. - Conduct of proceedings; issuance, service of subpoenas. 
(a)	The city attorney, or in case he be the accused, some attorney selected by the council, shall conduct the prosecution, and the accused shall be entitled to be represented by such counsel as he may employ to conduct his defense. 
(b)	The mayor or if he be the accused, then the president pro tempore of the council, shall issue subpoenas for such witnesses as may be called for by either party, and such subpoenas may be served by the proper officer of the city or by the sheriff or constable of the county and such officers and witnesses shall be entitled to the same fees as would be allowed for like services in the municipal court. 
(Code 1967, § 21-21)
Sec. 2-70. - Right of accused to be heard; prosecution to be by city attorney. 
    Upon any trial under this division, the accused shall be entitled to be heard by himself and his counsel in his defense, and the city attorney, or attorney acting for the city in the case shall attend and prosecute on behalf of the city. 
(Code 1967, § 21-22)
Sec. 2-71. - Compelling attendance of witnesses, production of papers; administering oaths. 
    The council shall have the power to compel the attendance of witnesses and the production of papers, relating to any subject under consideration under this division, in which the interest of the city is involved, and shall have the right to issue attachments for witnesses and call on the proper officers of the city or the sheriff or any constable of the county, to execute such process. The president of the council shall have the power to administer oaths to witnesses in all proceedings before the council under this division. 
(Code 1967, § 21-23)
Sec. 2-72. - Depositions of witnesses. 
    Depositions of witnesses beyond the jurisdiction of the council, or witnesses, prevented by sickness or other sufficient cause from attendance, may be read at the trial and instigation provided for herein, if taken in conformity to the laws of the state. The notice of this taking thereof, when taken on behalf of the accused, shall be served on the attorney representing the city. 
(Code 1967, § 21-24)
Sec. 2-73. - Vote, decision of council after hearing evidence. 
    As soon as the evidence at impeachment proceedings under this division has all been heard and the case submitted the council shall vote by ayes and noes upon the charges and specifications separately. The question upon each charge shall be, "Is the accused guilty?" If the charges that have been preferred by the mayor and the council by a majority vote of all the members elected to the council find the accused guilty of any one of the charges preferred, or, if the charges have been preferred by any member of the council and the council by a two-thirds majority vote of all the members elected thereto find the accused guilty of any one of the charges preferred, he may by resolution be removed from office; and if such resolution receive a vote of not less than two-thirds of the members elected to the council the office shall thereupon become and be vacant; provided, that if the charges preferred be that the accused is or has been directly or indirectly interested in any contract involving the city, or in any work done by said city or any of its institutions, the accused shall be dismissed from, and his office shall become and be vacant if the council by a majority vote of all the members elected find the accused guilty. 
(Code 1967, § 21-25)
Sec. 2-74. - Record of proceedings. 
    The proceedings of the council acting under this division shall be entered at large upon the journal of the proceedings of the council. 
(Code 1967, § 21-26)
Secs. 2-75-2-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CITY CLERK[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Appointment of officers, RSMo 77.330; duties of city clerk, RSMo 77.410; appointment of temporary clerk, RSMo 77.420; compensation of officers and employees, RSMo 77.440; officer to be resident, RSMo 77.380; bond, oath of officer, RSMo 77.390.

Sec. 2-81. - Creation, authority of office; duties generally. 
    The office of city clerk of the city is hereby created and established, and it shall be the duty of the mayor, subject to the concurrence of the city council, to select a competent and suitable person, qualified as the law requires, to fill and hold such office; and the duties of such officer shall be such as are prescribed by the statutes of the state; namely: 
(1)	Maintain the journal of the proceedings of council;
(2)	Safely and properly keep all records and papers belonging to the city;
(3)	Empowered to administer official oaths; also oaths to demand or claims against the city; 
(4)	Perform all duties required by ordinances of the city;
(5)	Provide other services as directed by the mayor.
(Code 1967, § 21-37; Ord. No. 6676, § 4, 2-1-93)
Sec. 2-82. - Term of office to be at pleasure of the mayor, subject to the concurrence of the city council. 
    The term of office of the city clerk shall be at the pleasure of the mayor, subject to the concurrence of the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 21-38)
Sec. 2-83. - Disqualification from office, grounds; bond. 
    No person shall be selected to the position of city clerk who at the time of such selection is in arrears for any unpaid city taxes, or forfeiture of defalcation in office. A bond of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) shall be filed with the premium paid by the city. 
(Code 1967, § 21-39; Ord. No. 6676, § 5, 2-1-93)
Sec. 2-84. - Additional compensation prohibited. 
    The salary of the city clerk shall be the only compensation the city clerk shall receive. 
(Code 1967, § 21-40)
Sec. 2-85. - Duties enumerated. 
    The city clerk shall: 
(1)	Control and check all payrolls, issue payroll checks. Maintain the personnel files on all city employees. Deposit and disburse all federal and state withholding taxes and social security deductions as required by law. Maintain the records and initiate the reporting and disbursing of retirement deductions for employees and the city's contribution. Prepare quarterly unemployment reports. Respond to all inquiries for workers' compensation claims. Disburse funds; 
(2)	Attend all meetings of the council and keep a correct record of its proceedings, and enter the same upon the journal; 
(3)	Affix the seal of the city to all instruments or documents, and official acts of the mayor, which by law or ordinance are required to be so attested, and countersign the same, and shall affix the seal of the city to and certify any record, document, copies of papers or ordinances, that may be required by any individual for any purpose, or that may be required for the use of any officer of the city; 
(4)	Prepare all certificates of elections, commissions and appointments or other official documents required by ordinance to be issued, or which the mayor in the discharge of his official duty is required to issue, and shall countersign the same and affix the seal of the city thereto; 
(5)	Prepare blank licenses for all purposes for which licenses are required or authorized to be issued, sign as city clerk and affixing the seal of the city thereto, collecting for the same and receipting therefor; 
(6)	Maintain a register of all licenses thus issued, including the date, to whom issued, and the amount of the tax due thereon, for what issued, and the date of expiration; 
(7)	Serve as ex officio license inspector of the city, and as such he shall see to it that all persons in the city doing business for which a license for the city is required, have licenses for such business as provided by ordinance, and report to the proper officials every person doing business without license; and if such person fails or refuses to take out a license as required by the ordinances of the city, the city clerk shall so inform the city attorney whose duty it shall be to prosecute said person for doing such business without a license from the city; 
(8)	Maintain the custody of all bonds of all officials any other bonds given to the city;
(9)	Maintain a register of all bonds and obligations of the city, date of issue, for what purpose issued, rate of interest, time of maturity, and the registered number of each bond and coupon, and as said bonds or coupons are paid or redeemed, he shall note such fact upon the register, giving the date of payment, the name of the party to whom payment was made, and file said bond or coupon in his office; 
(10)	Record all city ordinances passed, except such as are published in a revision, and shall neatly label and file for safekeeping, the original rolls of all ordinances or resolutions of the city council, and such other vouchers, papers and documents as may be delivered into his custody; 
(11)	Whenever any ordinance is passed amending or repealing any preexisting ordinance, or section or article thereof, by number or title thereof, the city clerk, at the time of recording such ordinance, shall note on the margin of the record thereof, so repealed or amended the number of the ordinance affecting such repealed or amended ordinance, or section thereof, the word "Repealed" or "Amended" as the case may be, by Ordinance No. _____; 
(12)	Organize and maintain a proper index of all records, ordinances, resolutions and other documents required by law or ordinance; 
(13)	Upon request, carefully and promptly execute every official duty that may be required by virtue of the laws of the state and the ordinances of the city; 
(14)	Serve as the general custodian of all books; papers, records, documents, belonging to the city, and at all times all records, accounts, transactions, documents or books of the city in his custody or control shall be subject to inspection by the public, or any citizen, but shall not be subject to be removed from the city hall, except by the city clerk; 
(15)	The city clerk shall not allow any of the records, papers, documents, etc., to be removed from the city hall, except by some officer of the city. Should any other responsible person desire to remove any of said records, documents, papers, etc., from the city hall, the city clerk shall allow such person to remove said papers for a time not to exceed thirty (30) days, but in such case the city clerk shall take a receipt from such person for such papers, and shall be held responsible for the return of such papers; 
(16)	Maintain the custody of the seal of the city, the public records including the journal of the proceedings of the council, the original ordinances and resolutions of the city council, and such other records and documents and papers as may be delivered for custody by the council. 
(Code 1967, §§ 21-41, 21-51; Ord. No. 6057, § 10, 2-4-85; Ord. No. 6676, § 6, 2-1-93)
Sec. 2-86. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 11 of Ord. No. 6057, adopted Feb. 4, 1985, repealed § 2-86, which section pertained to the keeping of tax records by the city clerk, and was derived from Code 1967, § 21-43. 
Sec. 2-87. - Deputy; appointment, function. 
    The mayor shall have the power, subject to approval of a majority of the council, to designate the city accountant to perform certain duties of the city clerk in the event of absence or illness. 
(Code 1967, § 21-44; Ord. No. 6057, § 12, 2-4-85)
Secs. 2-88-2-95. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - FINANCE DIRECTOR AND CITY ACCOUNTANT 

Sec. 2-96. - Creation, authority of office. 
    The office of finance director and city accountant of the city is hereby created and established, and it shall be the duty of the mayor subject to the concurrence of the city council to select a competent and suitable person, qualified as the law requires, to fill and hold such office. The terms finance director and city accountant shall be used interchangeably in this code. The position shall provide professional accounting management to the city's financial operations. The position shall initiate accounting guidelines, controls, procedures and practices to all departments and activities of the city's business. The position shall be under the direction of the mayor and shall perform in accordance with accepted and established accounting practices and conform to applicable city ordinances. 
(Code 1967, § 21-47; Ord. No. 5604, § 1, 8-18-80; Ord. No. 6676, § 8, 2-1-93)
Sec. 2-97. - Term of office to be at pleasure of the mayor, subject to the concurrence of the city council. 
    The term of office of the finance director shall be at the pleasure of the mayor, subject to the concurrence of the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 2-1-48; Ord. No. 5604, § 2, 8-18-80; Ord. No. 6676, § 11, 8-21-93)
Sec. 2-98. - Disqualification from office, grounds; bond. 
    No person shall be selected finance director who at the time of such selection is in arrears for any unpaid city taxes, or forfeiture of defalcation in office. A bond of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) shall be filed with the premium paid by the city. 
(Code 1967, § 21-49; Ord. No. 6676, §§ 9, 11, 2-1-93)
Sec. 2-99. - Additional compensation prohibited. 
    The salary of the finance director shall be the only compensation the finance director shall receive. 
(Code 1967, § 21-50; Ord. No. 6676, § 11, 2-1-93)
Sec. 2-100. - Duties enumerated. 
    The finance director shall: 
(1)	Be the general accountant of the city, and shall have the custody of all public account books, accounts, contracts, vouchers, documents, bonds and coupons paid or redeemed and all papers relating to accounts and contracts of the city and its revenues, debts and fiscal affairs, which are not required by law or ordinance to be kept by some other person or officer, and shall prepare all payrolls and quarterly unemployment reports; 
(2)	Conduct and maintain an inventory of all city-owned property, to include equipment, machinery, real estate and other facilities; 
(3)	Maintain a set of books at the city's expense, shall keep a true and current record of the city's fiscal affairs, and shall open an account thereon, between the city and all officers charged with the collection, custody or disbursement of public moneys, entering thereon all receipts and payments, from what sources derived and upon what account paid; 
(4)	Manage a complete record of all branches of the city revenue, opening an account with every fund which by law or ordinance is made a separate fund, crediting the same with all money paid into the city treasury on account thereof, and charging the fund with all warrants drawn thereon; 
(5)	Record and file away and preserve all accounts and claims presented against the city, and such as are allowed or payment by the city thereof authorized, shall be entered by said officer upon a record kept therefor, giving the date of allowance, the amount, the name of the claimant, and the general nature of the claim; and shall also keep a register of all warrants drawn upon the city accounts, specifying the number, date, and to whom payable, the amount and the fund against which the same was drawn; 
(6)	Prepare and draw all warrants, and shall express in the body of every warrant, the particular fund out of which same is paid; 
(7)	Provide information to the mayor or city council, when requested, upon questions relating to the fiscal affairs of the city, or concerning any of the duties of the office. 
(Code 1967, §§ 21-41, 21-51; Ord. No. 5604, § 3, 8-18-80; Ord. No. 6057, § 13, 2-4-85; Ord. No. 6676, §§ 10, 11, 2-1-93) 
Sec. 2-101. - Execution of warrants. 
    When any sum of money has been appropriated or ordered paid by the council, the finance director shall draw a warrant for such amount, which warrant shall be signed by the mayor and attested by the city clerk, with the seal of the city thereto affixed. 
(Code 1967, § 21-42; Ord. No. 6057, § 14, 2-4-85; Ord. No. 6676, § 11, 2-1-93)
Sec. 2-102. - Financial report to be given. 
(a)	At the regular meeting of the city council in January, April, July and October of each year, the finance director shall prepare for submission to the mayor and city council a report upon the financial affairs of the city, the report to contain a full and complete statement of all receipts and expenditures for the past fiscal year; including also a statement of the bonded indebtedness of the city, the amount of funds remaining in the treasury, the separate funds to which the same belongs, the amount of interest to be paid in the next fiscal year, and the bonds falling due during such time. 
(b)	The finance director shall in January and July of each year, make out a full and detailed statement of receipts and expenditures of the city for the half year ending December thirty-first and June thirtieth, preceding the date of the report, and file the same with the city council, which shall cause the same to be published in some newspaper published in the city. 
(Code 1967, § 21-52; Ord. No. 6676, § 12, 2-1-93)
Sec. 2-103. - Misuse of funds, warrants, other obligations. 
    The finance director shall be and is hereby prohibited from using, either directly or indirectly, for his own benefit or that of any other person, any money, warrant or other obligations of the city for safe custody or keeping, and any violations of this provision shall be deemed a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1967, § 21-53; Ord. No. 5604, § 4, 8-18-80; Ord. No. 6676, § 11, 2-1-93)
Sec. 2-104. - Misconduct in office. 
    It shall be unlawful for the finance director to willfully neglect or refuse to perform any of the duties enjoined by ordinance or by resolution of the mayor and council, or to be guilty of any oppression or extortion in the discharge of fiscal duties, or by cause of the position to do any act not authorized by ordinance. 
(Code 1967, § 21-54; Ord. No. 6676, § 11, 2-1-93)
Sec. 2-105. - Deputy; appointment, function. 
    The mayor shall have the power, subject to approval of a majority of the council, to designate the city clerk to perform certain duties of the finance director in the event of absence or illness. 
(Code 1967, § 21-55; Ord. No. 5604, § 5, 8-18-80; Ord. No. 6676, § 11, 2-1-93)
Secs. 2-106-2-110. - Reserved.
