DIVISION 6. - CITY ATTORNEY[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference- Election of city attorney, RSMo 77.370; duties, RSMo 98.330, 98.340; qualifications of city attorney, RSMo 77.370(2); residence requirements, RSMo 77.380; oath of city officers, RSMo 77.390; vacancy in office, RSMo 77.450.

Sec. 2-116. - Compensation. 
    The city attorney shall receive as compensation for his services the salary prescribed by the city council; and in addition thereto he shall receive in each case in which the city is a party in any court of record in the state or the United States, or in any hearing before the public service commission of the state, or in any other case in which the city attorney shall be directed by the city council or the mayor to appear and represent the city, a reasonable attorney's fee to be fixed by the city council and to be paid by the city; and provided that in each case appealed from the municipal court to the circuit court of the county, the city attorney shall receive an additional fee to be taxed as costs in the case; the attorney shall also receive as compensation for his services in suits on back taxes a commission of ten (10) percent of the amounts actually collected and paid into the treasury, and in suits in collections for back taxes against real estate, an additional fee for each suit instituted where publication is not necessary, and a fee for each suit instituted where publication is necessary, all such commissions and fees to be taxed as costs in such suit and paid by the party paying the taxes, and in no event shall the city be liable for the payment of any of such commissions or fees. 
(Code 1967, § 21-72)
Sec. 2-117. - Additional compensation prohibited. 
    The city attorney shall receive no compensation for his services other than that provided by this division. 
(Code 1967, § 21-73)
Sec. 2-118. - Duties enumerated. 
(a)	The city attorney shall prosecute all persons charged with violating the ordinances of the city, and to that end he shall attend the municipal court daily and prosecute all complaints, suits or proceedings that may be brought by the city therein or in which the city may be interested. 
(b)	The city attorney shall, if directed so to do by an order of record of the city council, attend to and prosecute on behalf of the city all suits instituted for the collection of delinquent and back taxes and all suits or proceedings brought to enforce payment of any other tax, license or revenue whatsoever, due the city. 
(Code 1967, § 21-74)
Sec. 2-119. - Opinions to be given. 
    The city attorney shall, without fee, give his opinion to any officer of the city respecting his duties, or respecting questions of law in which the city is interested, and such opinions shall be in writing when so demanded by the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 21-75)
Sec. 2-120. - Prosecution of appeals, writs of error in municipal court cases; reports. 
    The city attorney shall prosecute all appeals or writs of error in causes originating in the municipal court, and shall make all necessary affidavits therefor. He shall report to the city council, in writing, the condition of all suits pending in any court, which originated in municipal court, at the next meeting of the city council succeeding the adjournment of the court in which the same is pending. 
(Code 1967, § 21-76)
Sec. 2-121. - Effect of inability of city attorney to act. 
    In case of sickness, absence from the city, interest of the city attorney in the proceedings adverse to the interests of the city, or other temporary inability of the city attorney to discharge the duties of his office, he may, with the approval of the mayor and at his own expense, appoint some competent attorney to act in his stead during such temporary inability, in any proceedings pending before the municipal judge. If such appointment is not made as aforesaid, then it shall be the duty of the municipal judge to appoint some competent attorney to represent the city in all cases before his court, pending such temporary inability of the city attorney to perform the same, and the person so appointed shall possess the same powers and receive the same fees as the city attorney would receive if he were present and acting in the regular discharge of his duties. 
(Code 1967, § 21-77)
Sec. 2-122. - Effect of interest of city attorney in proceedings. 
    If the city attorney shall be interested in, or a party to any action brought by the city for the violation of any of its ordinances, or shall have been employed as counsel in any such case, previous to his election as city attorney, he shall inform the mayor and city council thereof, if the case be one which has been appealed or by other means removed from the municipal court; and the mayor and city council shall appoint some competent attorney at the expense of the city attorney to represent the city in such proceedings. 
(Code 1967, § 21-78)
Secs. 2-123-2-130. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - CITY COUNSELOR 

Sec. 2-131. - Office created. 
    The office of city counselor for the city is hereby created. 
(Code 1967, § 21-90)
Sec. 2-132. - Appointment, term. 
    The mayor, with the consent and approval of a majority of the city council, is hereby authorized to appoint a city counselor who shall serve at the pleasure of the council. 
(Code 1967, § 21-91)
Sec. 2-133. - Compensation. 
    The compensation to be paid the city counselor shall be fixed by ordinance or resolution of the city council, and shall be payable monthly. 
(Code 1967, § 21-92)
Sec. 2-134. - Duties. 
    The city counselor shall represent the city in all cases in all courts of record in this state; shall draft all ordinances and contracts and all legal forms of every kind; shall give legal advice to the council and other officers of the city; and shall perform such other duties as shall be prescribed by ordinance or shall be ordered by the council or the mayor. 
(Code 1967, § 21-93)
Secs. 2-135-2-140. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - CITY ADMINISTRATOR[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Editor's note-Section 11, Ord. No. 6107, adopted Aug. 19, 1985, repealed in its entirety Ord. No. 5971, adopted Apr. 17, 1984, section 1 of which pertained to the administrative assistant and was codified as Div. 8, §§ 2-141-2-149. Sections 1-10 of Ord. No. 6107, relative to the city administrator, have been added as Div. 8, §§ 2-141-2-150 at the discretion of the editor, the ordinance being not specifically amendatory of the Code.

Sec. 2-141. - Office created. 
    The position of city administrator for the City of Marshall, Missouri, is hereby created and the provisions of sections 2-142 through 2-150 shall apply at all times to said position. 
(Ord. No. 6107, § 1, 8-19-85)
Sec. 2-142. - Appointment and tenure. 
(a)	The city administrator shall be employed by a majority of the members elected to the city council, with the approval of the mayor. 
(b)	The city administrator shall serve at the pleasure of the appointing authority. The appointing authority may enter into a contract of employment with the city administrator for a term not to exceed two (2) years. Said contract shall provide that the city administrator may be removed at any time with or without cause, provided that, when removed without cause, said city administrator shall be paid the full amount remaining under the contract. For the purposes of this division, "removal with cause" shall mean: 
(1)	Obtaining materials on fraudulent orders, dishonesty, stealing and other criminal acts; 
(2)	Malicious destruction of city property;
(3)	Violation of any city ordinance or state statute relating to conflicts of interest;
(4)	Falsifying records, including payroll records;
(5)	Being under the influence of or use of intoxicating liquor, narcotics or other drugs while on the job; 
(6)	Failure to follow written policies and directives adopted by the mayor and the city council. 
(Ord. No. 6107, § 2, 8-19-85)
Sec. 2-143. - Qualifications. 
    The city administrator shall be at least twenty-five (25) years of age and a resident of Marshall during his tenure. In addition, the city administrator shall be a graduate of an accredited university or college with a major in public or municipal administration or shall have equivalent qualifications and experience in financial, administrative and/or public relations fields. 
(Ord. No. 6107, § 3, 8-19-85)
Sec. 2-144. - Bond. 
    The city administrator shall post a bond in the sum of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00). The premium for the bond shall be paid by the city. 
(Ord. No. 6107, § 4, 8-19-85; Ord. No. 6676, § 12, 2-1-93)
Sec. 2-145. - Compensation. 
    The compensation to be paid to the city administrator shall be fixed by ordinances passed by the city council, and shall be paid bi-weekly. 
(Ord. No. 6107, § 5, 8-19-85)
Sec. 2-146. - Duties. 
    The city administrator shall have general superintending control of the administration and management of the government business, officers and employees of the city, subject to the direction and supervision of the mayor. The city administrator's duties shall include, but not be limited, to the following: 
(a)	Administrative: Chief administrator assistant to the mayor, as such the administrative officer of the city's government who is directly responsible to the mayor and city council; 
(b)	Purchasing officer: Responsible for ensuring that all purchases are made in accordance with purchasing rules and procedures approved by the city council; 
(c)	Budget officer: Responsible for assembling estimates of financial needs and resources for each year, for approving all salary increases, expense accounts and travel requests, and for setting a program of activities within the financial capabilities of the city; 
(d)	Annual report: Shall present to the mayor and council an annual report for the fiscal year including summary reports of the activities of the various departments, etc. by January 1 of each year, and such other reports on the activities of the city as may be required by the mayor and council; 
(e)	Personnel officer: Responsible for ensuring that the personnel rules and regulations are followed by all departments, shall supervise and discipline all department heads and shall supervise, hire, fire and discipline all other city employees, all to the extent permitted by law; 
(f)	Policy formulation: Shall recommend to the city council adoption of measures which are deemed necessary for the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of Marshall, and shall recommend and institute administrative improvements and services; 
(g)	Council agenda and notice of meetings: Shall submit a proposed agenda before each regular council meeting and shall give notice of regular and special meetings; 
(h)	Boards and committees: Shall work with all city boards; attend meetings of the board of public works and city park board and coordinate the work of each board with all city departments; 
(i)	Council meetings: Shall attend all meetings of the city council, and shall review all contracts, leases, grants and other matters to be considered by the council; 
(j)	Bids: Shall supervise the preparation of all bid specifications for services and equipment; shall receive and open all bids in compliance with the city bid ordinance and submit a recapitulation and recommendation for acceptance to the appropriate authority; 
(k)	State and federal aid programs: Shall coordinate and apply for grants which may have application in the city. The community development program will remain under the direction of the Marshall Housing Authority; 
(l)	Conference attendance: Shall attend state and regional conferences and programs applicable to the administration or business of the city; 
(m)	Press releases: Shall be the official responsible for keeping the public informed of the business of the city and shall make releases available to local media as necessary. Department heads will be responsible for their respective departments as far as news releases are concerned, but all releases relating to statements of city policy shall be reviewed by the administrator before release; 
(n)	Record keeping: Shall keep full and accurate records of all actions in the course of his duties; 
(o)	Miscellaneous: Shall perform all other duties as assigned or prescribed by the mayor and council. 
(Ord. No. 6107, § 6, 8-19-85)
Sec. 2-147. - Powers. 
    The powers of the city administrator shall be as follows: 
(a)	City property: Shall be responsible for all property of the city; shall keep inventories; may sell property with approval of the council (real property may be sold only by ordinance authorization); 
(b)	Coordinate departments: Shall (1) coordinate the departments of the city, (2) have authority to assign employees of the city to any department where they can be used most effectively, and (3) coordinate the work priorities for the best overall services to the citizens; 
(c)	Investigations and reports: Shall have the power to investigate and examine or inquire into the affairs or operation of any department; shall have authority to review and revise all personnel actions, and to mediate and resolve all personnel disputes between employees and department heads. 
(Ord. No. 6107, § 7, 8-19-85)
Sec. 2-148. - Removal of city administrator. 
(a)	The city administrator shall serve at the pleasure of the mayor and city council, and may be removed prior to the expiration of the appointed term with or without cause by: 
(1)	The mayor with a majority of the members elected to the city council; or
(2)	By two-thirds (2/3) of the members elected to the council independent of the mayor's opposition;
(3)	By a vote of the people to change the form of city government.
(b)	Upon removal under subsections (a)(1) or (2) hereof, the city administrator may request a public hearing before the mayor and city council in writing. Said hearing shall be held within a reasonable time after notice of removal from office. The grievance procedures set forth in the city personnel policies shall not apply to the city administrator. 
(c)	The mayor may suspend the city administrator from duty without pay for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days, with approval of a majority of the members elected to the council. 
(d)	If removed from office by the mayor and/or the members of the city council without cause, the city administrator shall receive severance pay equal to the balance of the salary due under the contract referred to in section 2-142(b) hereof. 
(e)	If removed for cause, the city administrator's salary shall be immediately discontinued.
(Ord. No. 6107, § 8, 8-19-85)
Sec. 2-149. - Other duties, powers, responsibilities. 
    The city administrator shall assume any other duties, powers and responsibilities assigned by the mayor and members of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 6107, § 9, 8-19-85)
Sec. 2-150. - City administrator to perform former duties of administrative assistant, mayor. 
    All acts which fall under the authority granted to the city administrator, but which were previously required by city ordinances to be performed by the mayor or administrative assistant, shall to the extent permitted by state statutes be performed by the city administrator. All ordinances requiring the mayor or administrative assistant to perform said acts or which are in conflict with this division are hereby amended to require said acts and duties to be performed by the city administrator. 
(Ord. No. 6107, § 10, 8-19-85)
DIVISION 9. - CITY ENGINEER[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
State Law reference- Appointment of officers, RSMo 77.330.

Sec. 2-151. - Appointment. 
    The mayor, with the consent and approval of a majority of the members elected to the city council, shall have the power to appoint a part-time city engineer for a term of one (1) year at the first regular meeting of the council in which the newly elected members shall sit after the annual city election in April; provided that should such appointment not be made at such meeting, it may be made at any subsequent meeting of the council, for a term to terminate not later than the first regular meeting after the next annual city elections in which the newly elected members of the council shall participate. 
(Code 1967, § 21-122)
Sec. 2-152. - Qualifications. 
    The engineer appointed as provided in this division shall be registered by the state board of registration. 
(Code 1967, § 21-121)
Sec. 2-153. - Oath of office. 
    Before entering upon the duties of his office, the city engineer shall take upon himself and subscribe to an oath or affirmation before some court of record of the county, or the clerk of the city or the municipal judge of the same, that he possesses all of the qualifications prescribed by law for his office; that he will support the Constitution of the United States and of the state, the provisions of all the laws of this state affecting cities of the third class and the ordinances of the city, and faithfully demean himself in office, which official oath or affirmation shall be filed with the city clerk. 
(Code 1967, § 21-123)
State Law reference- Oath of city officer, RSMo 77.390. 
Sec. 2-154. - Compensation. 
    The compensation to be paid to the part-time city engineer shall be fixed by ordinance or resolution of the city council, but he shall not be employed more than fifteen (15) days per month. 
(Code 1967, § 21-124)
Sec. 2-155. - Duties enumerated. 
    The city engineer shall: 
(1)	Make and file with the city clerk all plans, specifications and estimates that may be necessary for the letting of contracts for construction of city projects or that may be necessary for the doing of work when it is not by contract; 
(2)	When so ordered by the mayor or council, prepare such plans, specifications, estimates and profiles, make such surveys, compile such data and submit such reports to the mayor or city council concerning projects or improvements which may be under consideration as the mayor or council may order; 
(3)	Make tests of materials used in the construction or reconstruction of streets, the building of sidewalks and curbing, the oiling of streets and such other city work as may be necessary; 
(4)	Recommend the grade, quality and kind of materials used in the doing of work for the city including road oils, asphalt, concrete, cement, sand and rock; 
(5)	Supervise and inspect all construction work of the city, without assuming control over or direction of any person who may be employed by a contractor in the doing of work for the city; 
(6)	Make such street, sidewalk, sewer, curb and drainage surveys, as the mayor or council may order, and report the proper grade to be established; 
(7)	Upon the completion of any work, the acceptance of which shall require the approval of the city engineer, the engineer, if he shall approve the same, shall submit such approval in writing to the council; 
(8)	Upon application, give the grade for sidewalks to be constructed with the city, and upon completion of any sidewalk if he shall find the same to have been built on grade, he shall file with the city clerk and furnish the owner his approval thereof in writing; 
(9)	Prescribe rules and regulations for the tapping of any public or district sewer by private parties, shall supervise and inspect any connections which may be made and shall approve the same in writing if he shall find them to have been properly made; 
(10)	Perform such duties as are required by the laws of the state, of a city engineer of a city of the third class, and as required by the ordinance of the city, and such other duties in addition to those set out, as he may, by the city council or director of municipal services be ordered to perform. 
(Code 1967, § 21-125; Ord. No. 6675, § 13, 2-1-93)
Sec. 2-156. - Instruments, equipment, books, data, etc.; custody, ownership. 
    The city shall furnish such instruments, equipment, field note books, drawing paper and other materials as shall by the council be deemed necessary, but all plats, profiles, maps, surveys, estimates, specifications, field notes, books and note books of data as may be made, compiled or begun by said engineer on city work, shall be the property of the city. 
(Code 1967, § 21-126)
Secs. 2-157-2-160. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 10. - DIRECTOR OF MUNICIPAL SERVICES[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Editor's note-Section 9 of Ord. No. 5947, adopted Feb. 21, 1984, changed the title of Div. 10 from "Street Commissioner" to "Director of Municipal Services." See also § 2-161(c) with regard to this change in terminology.
State Law reference- Bond of city officer, RSMo 77.390.

Sec. 2-161. - Appointment, oath; removal; assistant director. 
(a)	At the first meeting of the newly elected council after the annual city election, or as soon thereafter as practicable, it shall be the duty of the mayor, with the consent and approval of a majority of the members elected to the city council, to appoint some suitable and competent person to the office of director of municipal services, who shall be a resident of the city and who shall hold his office for a term of one year and until his successor is appointed and qualified. 
(b)	Before entering upon the duties of his office, the director shall take and subscribe an oath that he possesses all the qualifications prescribed by law for his office, that he will support the constitutions of the United States and of the state, all laws of the state, affecting cities of the third class and the ordinances of the city, that he will faithfully demean himself in office, and that he is not and will not during his term of office be either directly or indirectly interested in any contract with the city for any public work or material furnished, which official oath shall be filed with the city clerk. 
(c)	The director of municipal services shall serve as the street commissioner and the city traffic engineer. All references in the Code of Ordinances of the City of Marshall, Missouri to the "street commissioner" or city traffic engineer shall mean the "director of municipal services." 
(d)	The mayor shall, from time to time, with the consent and approval of a majority of the members elected to the city council, appoint some suitable and competent person to serve as the assistant director of the department of municipal services. It shall be the duty of the assistant director of the department of municipal services to perform the duties delegated to him by the director, and any acts required in the Code of Ordinances to be performed by the director may be delegated by him to the assistant director. 
(e)	In addition to the various duties set forth in the Code of Ordinances, the director of municipal services shall be responsible for all recordkeeping, coordination and administration of street maintenance, street construction, street sweeping and sign construction, equipment maintenance, administration of the city vehicle fuel system, residential and commercial refuse collection, operation of the city landfill, grant applications and administration on projects relating to the functions of the department and engineering-related duties. 
(f)	The director of municipal services may be removed from office in the manner prescribed for the removal of appointive officers of the city. 
(Code 1967, § 21-137; Ord. No. 59477, § 10, 2-21-84; Ord. No. 6676, § 14, 2-1-93)
State Law reference- Removal of city officer, RSMo 77.340; oath of city officer, RSMo 77.390. 
Sec. 2-162. - Duties enumerated. 
    The street commissioner shall: 
(1)	Give his personal attention to and direct the labor employed in the construction of any building, bridge, culvert, drain or sewer or in the improvement of any public park or other public place, where such work is done by the city and not under contract whenever so required by ordinance or resolution of the city council; 
(2)	Make such repairs on the streets and alleys of the city as may be immediately necessary for public safety and convenience, and is authorized and directed to make same without first obtaining an order therefor from the city council; 
(3)	See that all streets, alleys, sidewalks, gutters, drains and sewers are kept free from obstructions and in clean condition; 
(4)	Cause to be removed from all sidewalks and crossings any accumulation of snow, ice, mud, filth or other offensive matter, or anything calculated to impede the free and unobstructed passage of pedestrians; 
(5)	Keep a general supervision over the streets, alleys and public places of the city and recommend to the council from time to time any necessary improvements therein, and shall designate to the chief of police work for prisoners that may be required to labor on public work on streets; 
(6)	See that all sidewalks are kept in good condition and repair, and shall at any time report to the committee on streets, alleys, sidewalks and sewers for their information and action what new sidewalks, in his judgment, should be constructed; 
(7)	Cause to be removed any dead animals or fowl or other nuisance he may find in or upon any street, alley, sidewalk or thoroughfare or other public place within the city; 
(8)	Where excavations are made in public places under contract with or permit from the city, see that the work of refilling the same and of restoring the pavement, sidewalk or other surface is done in a proper manner and without injury to the city or any citizen thereof, and shall report to the chief of police the violation of any ordinance or the terms of their permit, committed by any contractor or permittee with the city, making such excavations; 
(9)	At the first regular meeting of the council in each month, submit in writing an itemized and detailed report of the work done by him during the preceding month, specifying the character of the work, when performed, the number of men employed, days of service by each, prices paid per day, materials and tools purchased and the cost thereof, and the total expenditures or obligations for payment for which the city is responsible. 
(Code 1967, § 21-138)
Sec. 2-163. - Use of personnel, equipment; purchases. 
    The street commissioner, by and with the advice and consent of the council, is hereby authorized and empowered to use such laborers, mechanics, vehicles, carts and teams, and to purchase such materials and tools as from time to time may be necessary in the proper discharge of his duties; provided, that the wages of laborers and mechanics and the compensation allowed for vehicles, carts or teams so used shall in no event, exceed the rate of compensation usually paid in the city for similar services at the time of such use. 
(Code 1967, § 21-139)
Sec. 2-164. - Custody of equipment. 
    The street commissioner shall have the care and custody of all tools, machinery, implements and other property of the city under his control in the performance of his duties, and shall be held responsible for their loss or abuse and upon vacating his office he shall cause the same to be turned over to his successor in office, or to the committee on streets, alleys, sidewalks and sewers if his successor shall not have been appointed and qualified and he shall take duplicate receipts for all property so transferred; one copy of which he shall file with the city clerk. 
(Code 1967, § 21-140)
Sec. 2-165. - Accounts to be kept. 
    The street commissioner shall keep an accurate, itemized account of all purchases made by him and of all services rendered by those in his employ or under his control, and shall certify to the correctness of all accounts for purchases made by him, and for services rendered by the persons, vehicles, carts and teams under his control. 
(Code 1967, § 21-141)
Sec. 2-166. - Prosecution of violators. 
    The street commissioner shall cause to be prosecuted every person he may find violating any ordinance of the city relating to streets, alleys, sidewalks, sewers or other public property of the city and shall make arrests of all persons violating such ordinances and bringing them before the municipal judge. 
(Code 1967, § 21-142)
Sec. 2-167. - Additional duties. 
    The street commissioner shall perform such other duties as may hereafter be prescribed by ordinance or resolution of the council. 
(Code 1967, § 21-143)
Secs. 2-168-2-175. - Reserved.

    The personnel policies of the city shall be those presently established or as hereafter adopted by the city council and kept on file in the city clerk's office. 
Secs. 2-177-2-277. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 12. - BENEFITS 
Subdivision I. - In General 

Secs. 2-278-2-285. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Old Age and Survivor's Insurance[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
State Law reference- Agreement of political subdivision with state, respecting Old Age and Survivors Insurance, RSMo 105.350; contributions by political subdivisions, employees, RSMo 105.370; rules and regulations, RSMo 105.430.

Sec. 2-286. - Extension to eligible employees. 
    It shall be the policy and purpose of the city to extend to all eligible employees and officials of the city who are not excluded by law or by this subdivision, and whether employed in connection with a governmental or proprietary function of said city, the benefits of the system of federal old-age and survivors insurance as authorized by the Social Security Act amendments and by the general assembly of the state, as the same may be now and hereafter in effect. 
(Code 1967, § 21-199)
Sec. 2-287. - Submission to state of plan and agreement, amendments thereto. 
    The mayor and city clerk shall, on behalf of this city, prepare, execute and submit to the division of budget and comptroller of the state, as state agency of the state, a plan and agreement for extending benefits hereunder to the eligible employees and officials of the city, in the form prepared by the state agency and hereby approved and adopted by the city council, which plan and agreement shall become effective upon approval thereof by the state agency; and shall execute agreements and modifications and amendments thereof with the state agency, providing for the extension of such benefits to the employees and officials as set forth in the plan and agreement, as provided for in section 2-286. 
(Code 1967, § 21-200)
Sec. 2-288. - Contributions to fund by employees. 
    There shall be deducted from the wages of all employees and officials of the city to whom the benefits of the system of federal old age and survivor's insurance are extended, by virtue of the plan and agreement hereinbefore provided for, the amount of each of the employees' and officials' contributions, as determined by applicable state and federal laws and by the plan and agreement, the aggregate amount of said deductions to be paid into the contributions fund created by the general assembly of the state. 
(Code 1967, § 21-201)
Sec. 2-289. - Contributions to fund by city. 
    There shall be appropriated from the various funds of the city the sum or sums of money necessary to pay the contributions of the city which shall be due and payable by virtue of the extension of the benefits of the federal old age and survivor's insurance system to the eligible employees and officials of the city, said sum or sums of money to be paid into the contributions fund created by the general assembly of the state. The fund from which the appropriation is made shall at all times, be sufficient to pay the contributions of the city by this section directed to be paid to the contributions fund. 
(Code 1967, § 21-202)
Sec. 2-290. - Records, reports, administration of plan and agreement. 
    The city shall fully comply with, and shall keep such records, make such reports and provide such methods of administration of the plan and agreement provided for in this subdivision as may be required by all applicable state and federal laws, rules and regulations, now and hereafter in effect with respect to the extension of the benefits of the federal old age and survivor's insurance system to the employees and officials of this city. For the purpose of administering the plan and agreement the city clerk shall be the official who shall make all required reports, keep all records, and be responsible for the administration of the plan and agreement on behalf of the city, and any and all notices and communications from the state agency to the city with respect to the plan and agreement shall be addressed to "City Clerk, Marshall, Missouri." 
(Code 1967, § 21-203)
Secs. 2-291-2-295. - Reserved. 
Subdivision III. - Local Government Employees Retirement System[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
State Law reference- Retirement or pensioning of officers and employees of political subdivisions, RSMo 70.600 et seq.

Sec. 2-296. - City's participation in system; employee coverage; benefit program. 
(a)	The city hereby elects to have covered by the Missouri Local Government Employees Retirement System all its eligible employees in the following classes: 
(1)	Present and future firemen;
(2)	Present and future general employees;
(3)	Present and future policemen.
(b)	The city hereby elects that one hundred (100) percent of prior employment be considered for prior service credit in computing benefits and contributions to the system. 
(c)	The city hereby elects to to adopt a change in the benefit program of member employees, changing to Benefit Program L-12 (1.75;%) 
(Code 1967, § 21-206; Ord. No. 7386, § 1, 3-25-02; Ord. No. 7660, § 1, 11-21-05)
Sec. 2-297. - Employee and employer contributions. 
    The finance director is hereby authorized and directed to deduct from the wages and salaries of each employee member the member contributions required by RSMo 70.705, and to promptly remit the deductions to the retirement system, together with the employer contributions required by RSMo 70.730. Employee and employer contributions are to be effective April 1, 1971. 
(Code 1967, § 21-207; Ord. No. 6676, § 15, 2-1-93)
Subdivision IV. - Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 

Sec. 2-298. - Administration of the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993. 
    All request for use of the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 (the "Act") by employees shall be made to the City Administrator of the City of Marshall. All requests for family and medical leave shall be in accordance with the provisions of the Act. Eligible employees shall be entitled to family leave in accordance with the Act and this ordinance [subdivision]. The City Administrator of the City is authorized to take whatever steps deemed necessary to administer the Act. 
(Ord. No. 7182, § 1, 5-3-99)
Sec. 2-299. - Determination of twelve-month period. 
    It is hereby determined that for purposes of computing the twelve-month period in which the twelve weeks of leave entitlement occurs, the City shall use the twelve-month period measured forward from the date any employee's first such leave begins. 
(Ord. No. 7182, § 1, 5-3-99)
Sec. 2-300. - Substitution of paid leave. 
    The City Administrator may require an eligible employee to substitute any of the accrued paid vacation leave, personal leave, family leave, holiday leave or sick leave that the employee is otherwise entitled to for leave provided under subparagraph (A), (B) or (C) or subsection (a)(1) of 29 USC 2612. 
    The City Administrator may require an eligible employee to substitute any of the accrued paid vacation leave, personal leave, holiday, or medical or sick leave for leave that the employee is otherwise entitled to for leave provided under subparagraph (C) or (D) of subsection (a)(1) of 29 USC 2612. 
    Nothing contained herein shall be construed to require the City of Marshall pay benefits in any such situation in which the City would not normally provide paid leave. 
(Ord. No. 7182, § 1, 5-3-99)
Sec. 2-301. - Leave taken intermittently or on a reduced leave schedule. 
    If an eligible employee requests intermittent leave or leave on a reduced leave scheduled under subparagraph (C) or (D) of subsection (a)(1) of 29 USC 2612 that is foreseeable based on planned medical treatment, the City Administrator may require such employee to transfer temporarily to an available alternate position offered by the City for which the employee is qualified provided there is equivalent pay and benefits and the position better accommodates the recurring periods of leave than the regular employment position of the employee. 
(Ord. No. 7182, § 1, 5-3-99)
Sec. 2-302. - Accrual of benefits. 
    Any eligible employee who takes family leave in accordance with the provisions of the Act without pay shall not be entitled to the accrual of any seniority or employment benefits during any period of leave or any right, benefit or position of employment other than any right, benefit, or position to which the employee would have been entitled if the employee had not taken leave. 
(Ord. No. 7182, § 1, 5-3-99)
Sec. 2-303. - Recoupment of medical insurance costs. 
    If an employee does not return to work after the employee has taken family leave without pay under provisions of the Act, the City shall be authorized to take whatever legal action necessary to recoup health insurance costs incurred by the City during the time that the employee took the family leave. 
(Ord. No. 7182, § 1, 5-3-99)
Sec. 2-304. - Spouses employed by the city. 
    In any case in which a husband and wife entitled to leave under subsection (a) of 29 USC 2612 are employed by the City, the aggregate number of workweeks of leave to which both may be entitled shall be limited to 12 workweeks during any 12-month period, if such leave is taken under subparagraph (A) or (B) of subsection (a)(1) of 29 USC 2612; or to care for a sick parent under subparagraph (C) of subsection (a)(1) of 29 USC 2612. 
(Ord. No. 7182, § 1, 5-3-99)
Sec. 2-305. - [Authorization of special leave.] 
    Nothing contained in Subdivision IV pertaining to the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 shall limit the city from authorizing special leave in addition to the family and medical leave otherwise provide herein. 
(Ord. No. 7182, § 1, 5-3-99)
DIVISION 13. - CONFLICTS OF INTEREST 

Sec. 2-306. - Declaration of policy. 
    The proper operation of government requires that public officials and employees be independent, impartial and responsible to the people; that government decisions and policy be made in the proper channels of the governmental structure; that public office not be used for personal gain; and that the public have confidence in the integrity of its government. In recognition of these goals, there is hereby established a procedure for disclosure by certain officials and employees of private financial or other interests in matters affecting the City. 
(Ord. No. 7267, § 1, 7-17-00; Ord. No. 7336, § 1, 7-16-01; Ord. No. 7403, § 1, 7-15-02; Ord. No. 7473, § 1, 7-21-03; Ord. No. 7550, § 1, 7-19-04; Ord. No. 7629, § 1, 7-18-05; Ord. No. 7694, § 1, 7-17-06; Ord. No. 7761, § 1, 7-16-07; Ord. No. 7825, § 1, 7-21-08; Ord. No. 7889, § 1, 7-20-09; Ord. No. 7951, § 1, 7-19-10; Ord. No. 8005, § 1, 7-18-11; Ord. 8057, § 1, 7-16-12; Ord. No. 8122, § 1, 8-5-13; Ord. No. 8167, § 1, 7-7-14; Ord. No. 8222, § 1, 7-6-15) 
Sec. 2-307. - Conflicts of interest. 
(a)	All elected and appointed officials, as well as employees of the City serving in an executive or administrative capacity, must comply with Section 105.454 of the Missouri Revised Statutes related to conflicts of interest as well as any other state law governing official conduct. 
(b)	Any member of the Council of the City who has a "substantial personal or private interest" in any measure, bill, order or ordinance proposed or pending before such governing body must disclose that interest to the Clerk of such body and such disclosure shall be recorded in the ethics disclosure journal of the City as established by the Clerk. Substantial personal or private interest is defined as ownership by the individual, the individual's spouse, or the individual's dependent children, whether singularly or collectively, directly or indirectly, of: 
(1)	Ten percent (10%), or more, of any business entity; or
(2)	An interest having a value of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) or more; or
(3)	The receipt by the individual, the individual's spouse, or the individual's dependent children, whether singularly or collectively, of a salary, gratuity, or other compensation or remuneration of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) or more, per year, from any individual, partnership, organization, or association within any calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 7267, § 2, 7-17-00; Ord. No. 7336, § 2, 7-16-01; Ord. No. 7403, § 2, 7-15-02; Ord. No. 7473, § 2, 7-21-03; Ord. No. 7550, § 2, 7-19-04; Ord. No. 7629, § 2, 7-18-05; Ord. No. 7694, § 2, 7-17-06; Ord. No. 7761, § 2, 7-16-07; Ord. No. 7825, § 2, 7-21-08; Ord. No. 7889, § 2, 7-20-09; Ord. No. 7951, § 2, 7-19-10; Ord. No. 8005, § 2, 7-18-11; Ord. No. 8057, § 2, 7-16-12; Ord. No. 8122, § 2, 8-5-13; Ord. No. 8167, § 2, 7-7-14; Ord. No. 8222, § 2, 7-6-15) 
Sec. 2-308. - Disclosure reports. 
    Each elected official, candidate for elective office, the chief administrative officer, the chief purchasing officer, and the full-time general counsel, if any, shall disclose the following information by May 1, or by the appropriate deadline as referenced in Section 105.487, RSMo., if any such transactions occurred during the previous calendar year: 
(1)	For such person, and all persons within the first degree of consanguinity or affinity of such person, the date and the identities of the parties to each transaction with a total value in excess of five hundred dollars ($500.00), if any, that such person had with the City, other than compensation received as an employee or payment of any tax, fee or penalty due to the City, and other than transfers for no consideration to the City. 
(2)	The date and the identities of the parties to each transaction known to the person with a total value in excess of five hundred dollars ($500.00), if any, that any business entity in which such person had a substantial interest, had with the City, other than payment of any tax, fee or penalty due to the City or transactions involving payment for providing utility service to the City, and other than transfers for no consideration to the City. 
(3)	The chief administrative officer and the chief purchasing officer for the City, and candidates or applicants for those offices, also shall disclose in writing, by May 1, or by the appropriate deadline as referenced in Section 105.487, RSMo., the following information for the previous calendar year: 
a.	The name and address of each of the employers of such person from whom income of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), or more, was received during the year covered by the statement; 
b.	The name and address of each sole proprietorship that he owned; the name, address and the general nature of the business conducted of each general partnership and joint venture in which he was a partner or participant; the name and address of each partner or co-participant for each partnership or joint venture unless such names and addresses are filed by the partnership or joint venture with the Secretary of State; the name, address and general nature of the business conducted of any closely-held corporation or limited partnership in which the person owned ten percent (10%), or more, of any class of the outstanding stock or limited partnership units; and the name of any publicly traded corporation or limited partnership that is listed on a regulated stock exchange or automated quotation system in which the person owned two percent (2%), or more, of any class of outstanding sock, limited partnership units or other equity interests; and 
c.	The name and address of each corporation for which such person served in the capacity of a director, officer or receiver. 
(Ord. No. 7267, § 3, 7-17-00; Ord. No. 7336, § 3, 7-16-01; Ord. No. 7403, § 3, 7-15-02; Ord. No. 7473, § 3, 7-21-03; Ord. No. 7550, § 3, 7-19-04; Ord. No. 7629, § 3, 7-18-05; Ord. No. 7694, § 3, 7-17-06; Ord. No. 7761, § 3, 7-16-07; Ord. No. 7825, § 3, 7-21-08; Ord. No. 7889, § 3, 7-20-09; Ord. No. 7951, § 3, 7-19-10; Ord. No. 8005, § 3, 7-18-11; Ord. No. 8057, § 3, 7-16-12; Ord. No. 8122, § 3, 8-5-13; Ord. No. 8167, § 3, 7-7-14; Ord. No. 8222, § 3, 7-6-15) 
Sec. 2-309. - Filing of reports. 
(a)	The financial interest statements shall be filed at the following times, but no person is required to file more than one (1) financial interest statement in any calendar year: 
(1)	Every person required to file a financial interest statement shall file the statement annually, not later than May 1, and the statement shall cover the calendar year ending the immediately preceding December 31; provided that any member of the City Council may supplement the financial interest statement to report additional interests acquired after December 31 of the covered year until the date of filing of the financial interest statement; 
(2)	Each person appointed to office shall file the statement within thirty (30) days of such appointment or employment covering the calendar year ending the previous December 31; and 
(3)	Every candidate required to file a personal financial disclosure statement shall file no later than fourteen (14) days after the close of filing at which the candidate seeks nomination or election or nomination by caucus. The time period of this statement shall cover the twelve (12) months prior to the closing date of filing for candidacy. 
(b)	Financial disclosure reports giving the financial information required in Section 2-308 shall be filed with the City and the Missouri Ethics Commission. The reports shall be available for public inspection and copying during normal business hours. 
(Ord. No. 7267, § 4, 7-17-00; Ord. No. 7336, § 4, 7-16-01; Ord. No. 7403, § 4, 7-15-02; Ord. No. 7473, § 4, 7-21-03; Ord. No. 7550, § 4, 7-19-04; Ord. No. 7629, § 4, 7-18-05; Ord. No. 7694, § 4, 7-17-06; Ord. No. 7761, § 4, 7-16-07; Ord. No. 7825, § 4, 7-21-08; Ord. No. 7889, § 4, 7-20-09; Ord. No. 7951, § 4, 7-19-10; Ord. No. 8005, § 4, 7-18-11; Ord. No. 8057, § 4, 7-16-12; Ord. No. 8122, § 4, 8-5-13; 8222, § 4, 7-6-15)

DIVISION 2. - BAND COMMISSION[15] 

Footnotes: 
--- (15) --- 
State Law reference- Tax for band fund authorized, RSMo 71.640 et seq.

Sec. 2-316. - Establishment. 
    There is hereby established within the city a commission, to be known as the band commission. 
(Code 1967, § 2-10)
Sec. 2-317. - Composition. 
    The band commission shall consist of three (3) members who shall be residents of the city. 
(Code 1967, § 2-10)
Sec. 2-318. - Appointment. 
    The members of the band commission shall be appointed by the mayor annually for a term commencing from the first regular meeting of the city council in each year, following the city election in April. 
(Code 1967, § 2.10)
Sec. 2-319. - Compensation. 
    The members of the band commission shall receive no compensation for their services, nor shall the city be liable in any way for any services performed by the commission or the members thereof. 
(Code 1967, § 2-11)
Sec. 2-320. - Vacancies. 
    In case of a vacancy on the band commission, such vacancy shall be filled for the unexpired term of appointment by the mayor. 
(Code 1967, § 2-10)
Sec. 2-321. - Authority. 
    The band commission shall have a supervising control over all matters connected with the municipal band. The commission, subject to the approval of the city council, shall contract with the authorized officials of a band or other municipal civic musical organizations for its employment in the giving of free band concerts, or equivalent musical services by the band or other municipal civic musical organizations under the jurisdiction of the band commission upon such occasions of public importance as may be agreed upon and stipulated in such contract, and shall advise with the council upon all matters pertaining thereto; provided, that no contract or agreement made by the commission shall be binding upon the city until the same shall have been approved by the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 2.12)
DIVISION 3. - ENHANCED ENTERPRISE ZONE BOARD 

Sec. 3-322. - Administration of board. 
    The enhanced enterprise zone board, established pursuant to the Resolution adopted on May 16, 2005, shall be governed by the following provisions: 
(1)	There shall be seven (7) members on the enhanced enterprise zone board. One (1) member of the board shall be appointed by the school district or districts located within the area proposed for designation as an enhanced enterprise zone. One (1) member of the board shall be appointed by other affected taxing districts. The remaining five (5) members shall be chosen by the mayor, with the approval of the city council. 
(2)	The school district member and the affected taxing district member shall each have initial terms of five (5) years. Of the five (5) members appointed by the mayor, two (2) shall have initial terms of four (4) years, two (2) shall have initial terms of three (3) years, and one (1) shall have an initial term of two (2) years. Thereafter, members shall serve terms of five years. Each commissioner shall hold office until a successor has been appointed. All vacancies shall be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. For inefficiency or neglect of duty or misconduct in office, a member of the board may be removed by the applicable appointing authority. 
(3)	A majority of the members shall constitute a quorum of such board for the purpose of conducting business and exercising the powers of the board and for all other purposes. Action may be taken by the board upon a vote of a majority of the members present. 
(4)	The members of the board annually shall elect a chair from among the members.
(5)	The role of the Board shall be to conduct the activities necessary to advise the mayor and the council of the city on the designation of an enhanced enterprise zone and any other advisory duties as may hereafter be determined by the mayor and the council of the city. The role of the board after the designation of an enhanced enterprise zone shall be review and assessment of zone activities as it relates to the annual reports as set forth in and required by RSMo. §135.960. 
(Ord. No. 7633, § 1, 7-18-05)
Secs. 2-322.1-2-322.7. - Reserved.

ARTICLE V. - FINANCE AND PURCHASING[17] 
Footnotes: 
--- (17) --- 
Cross reference- Any appropriation ordinance saved from repeal, § 1-5(4); taxation generally, Ch. 28.
State Law reference- Financial administration and indebtedness, RSMo Ch. 95.

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-331. - Fiscal year. 
    The fiscal year of the city shall begin upon the first day of October each year, and shall end on the thirtieth day of September thereafter, and the books, accounts, records, and reports of all city officers and departments shall conform thereto. 
(Code 1967, § 13-1)
Sec. 2-332. - Records of city finances to be kept. 
    In order that the state of the city's funds can be ascertained at any time, the finance director shall and is hereby directed to prepare, keep and maintain adequate records of the city's finances, the same to be kept according to standard accounting procedures and practices. 
(Code 1967, § 13-2; Ord. No. 6676, § 18, 2-1 -93)
Sec. 2-333. - Access of treasurer, city clerk to books, accounts and papers. 
    The treasurer, finance director and city clerk shall have free access to each others offices for the inspection of all books, accounts and papers which they respectively contain, and full access to all other offices of the city for the inspection of such books, accounts and papers as concerning any of their duties. 
(Code 1967, § 13-3; Ord. No. 6676, § 19, 2-1-93)
Sec. 2-334. - Audit of books covering city finances, required. 
    Annually during the month of October the books of the city covering its finances shall be audited for the year ending on the thirtieth day of September preceding, such audit to be made by such competent accountant as the city may employ for that pui-pose. 
(Code 1967, § 13-4)
Sec. 2-335. - Sale of unclaimed personal property; disposition of proceeds. 
(a)	The chief of police shall be authorized to sell all unclaimed personal property recovered by the police department. Items shall be retained by the police department for at least sixty (60) days from the date of possession. If the property is not claimed by its owner within sixty (60) days, the chief of police may sell the property. 
(b)	All sales of personal property, except firearms, shall be at public auction. The city clerk shall cause notice of the sale to be published in a local newspaper at least seven (7) days prior to the sale. 
(c)	Firearms shall be offered for sale by sealed bid to dealers licensed by the U. S. Department of Treasury, Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. The highest and best bid shall be accepted. The chief of police shall have the discretion to destroy any firearm he deems inappropriate for sale. 
(d)	The proceeds of the sale, after deducting the expenses of sale, shall be deposited in the general revenue fund of the city and shall be accompanied by an itemized list of the expenses of sale, and a verified list identifying the article sold, the sale price, and the name of the purchaser. 
(Code 1967, § 13-15; Ord. No. 6852, § 1, 3-6-95)
Secs. 2-336-2-340. - Reserved.

Footnotes:

(Code 1967, § 13-5)
Sec. 2-342. - Sources of revenue, receipts.
