(Code 1967, § 13-6)
Sec. 2-343. - Disbursements, expenditures. 
    Disbursements and expenditures from each of the funds described in section 2-341 shall be as provided for in the annual budget adopted by the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 13-7)
Sec. 2-344. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6676, § 20, adopted Feb. 1, 1993, amended this Code by repealing § 2-344, pertaining to the equipment replacement reserve fund, as derived from § 13-8 of the 1967 Code. 
Sec. 2-345. - Sanitation fund. 
(a)	Source. All moneys received by the city for services provided by the city in the collection of ashes, trash and garbage shall be deposited in the sanitation fund herein created and established. 
(b)	Use. All moneys deposited in the sanitation fund shall be used for the necessary current expenses of the ash, trash and garbage department and for the purchase of necessary equipment therefor. 
(Code 1967, § 13-9)
Sec. 2-346. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6365, § 3, adopted Nov. 7, 1988, repealed § 2-346, which pertained to the parking lot fund and derived from § 13-10 of the city's 1967 Code. 
Sec. 2-347. - Tax surplus fund. 
(a)	Created. There is hereby created and established a special fund to be known as the "tax surplus fund." 
(b)	Source. Whenever real estate shall be sold by the city collector for the payment of real estate taxes assessed against any tract, parcel or lot of land within the corporate limits of the city, for the purpose of collecting the real estate taxes assessed thereon and the collector shall receive from the sale an amount of money in excess of the amount of taxes due thereon and the costs of the sale, and the owner or agent cannot be found, the city collector shall pay over such amount in excess of taxes and costs to the finance director and shall receive from said finance director his receipt for the same, upon receipt of which the city collector shall take credit for the amount so paid over to the finance director. 
(c)	Custody. The finance director shall deposit the amount so received from the city collector in the "tax surplus fund" where such moneys shall be kept until the city council shall order the disposition thereof. 
(d)	Trust established. The moneys placed in the "tax surplus fund" shall be held in trust by the finance director for the term of twenty (20) years for the owner or his legal representatives, and if at the end of twenty (20) years, such moneys shall not be called for then the city council may direct the transfer of such moneys to any fund which it may desire. 
(e)	Claim by owner. At any time within twenty (20) years after the payment into said "tax surplus fund" of any moneys as aforesaid the owner of the land so sold or his legal representatives may appear before the city council making claim for such moneys, and upon the making of proof satisfactory to the city council, the city council shall order the finance director to pay said moneys to the person claiming it; provided however, that no interest shall be paid. 
(Code 1967, § 13-11; Ord. No. 6676, § 11, 2-1-93)
Sec. 2-348. - Consolidation of surplus monies for individual accounting funds for investment purposes. 
    All monies for each accounting fund of the city shall be accounted for separately after which they may be consolidated for investment purposes; all interest becoming due to each accounting fund from such investments shall be paid to the respective accounting fund and credited thereto upon receipt by the consolidated investment fund. From the time of transfer the consolidated surplus funds shall be invested within three (3) working days; if no investment is made thereof within this period, the surplus monies shall be returned to the appropriate fund. The authority to initiate the transfer of surplus monies and to commit such investments shall rest in the city council pursuant to considerations including but not limited to: Timing, need, limitations and consideration of various financial institutions. 
(Code 1967, § 13-13)
Sec. 2-349. - Officers authorized to deposit and withdraw funds belonging to investment fund account. 
    A combination of any two (2) signatures of the following designated officers of the city shall be required for the deposit or withdrawal of any funds belonging to the designated "investment fund account" for consolidated city fund investment pursuant to section 2-348 with any banking, loan or financial institution in which the city has established such a fund; the officers are: 
(1)	City clerk;
(2)	Mayor; and
(3)	Finance director.
(Code 1967, § 13-14; Ord. No. 6057, § 15, 2-4-85; Ord. No. 6676, § 11, 2-1-93)
Secs. 2-350-2-355. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PAYMENT OF CLAIMS[19] 

Footnotes: 
--- (19) --- 
State Law reference- Presentation and allowance of claims, RSMo 95.315; penalty for corrupt allowance of claims, RSMo 77.460.

Sec. 2-356. - Preparation, presentation of warrant; sufficiency of funds. 
    Whenever the city shall become liable to any person in any amount and the claim has been properly audited by the city council and allowed as provided by ordinance, it shall be the duty of the city clerk to make out a warrant for the same, which he shall attest and present to the mayor for his signature, provided that there be sufficient money in the treasury to the credit of the fund to which said claim properly belongs, out of which it shall be paid, as provided by ordinance to pay the said warrants on demand; should there not be money in the treasury out of which to pay warrants drawn, the mayor and clerk shall not be allowed to draw any warrant on the fund. 
(Code 1967, § 13-23)
Sec. 2-357. - Warrant not to be drawn until allowed by council. 
    No warrant shall be drawn on the treasury for any sum for any purpose, unless the claim for the payment of which it is issued shall be first allowed by the city council. This shall apply to salaries of the city officers as well as all other claims against the city. 
(Code 1967, § 13-24)
Sec. 2-358. - Restrictions upon appropriations, warrants. 
    No appropriation of money shall be made by the mayor and council, and no warrant shall be drawn by the city clerk or paid by the finance director unless the amount of money remaining in the treasury to the credit of the fund upon which the warrant is drawn shall be sufficient to pay the same. It shall be unlawful for any councilman to vote to appropriate any sum out of the treasury, or order a warrant therefor, without the endorsement of the treasurer that there is a sufficient sum in the fund for the payment of the warrant, or appropriation. 
(Code 1967, § 13-25; Ord. No. 6676, § 11, 2-1-93)
Sec. 2-359. - Appropriations, contracting indebtedness in excess of income of general fund. 
    It shall be unlawful for the city council to make appropriation or contract any indebtedness whatsoever, for any purpose, out of the general fund, exceeding the income of the fund, excluding commissions to officers, abatements of licenses and taxes and delinquent taxes for any fiscal year, or allow any claim unless there is money in the treasury to pay the same. 
(Code 1967, § 13-26)
Sec. 2-360. - City to defend and make payment of certain claims against city officers, employees, boards and commissions. 
(a)	The city council may authorize the proper officers to pay compensatory damage claims arising out of a civil or criminal action or threat of civil or criminal action, or settlements, judgments, expenses and costs, and awards of attorneys' fees arising therefrom against any present, future or former city employee, officer, agent, member of any city board or commission, or member of the city council when the city council determines that such claims resulted from activities which are done: 
(1)	In good faith; and
(2)	In the reasonable belief that such activities were in the best interest of the city and in the furtherance of the official practices and policies of the city; 
(3)	Within the scope of authority of the person so acting;
(4)	Within the course of employment of the person so acting;
(5)	Not willful, malicious or wanton.
(b)	Nothing in this section shall be construed as waiving the city's defense of governmental function or governmental immunity in any action brought against the city or its employees, officers, agents, members of any city board or commission, or members of the city council for damages. 
(c)	The city council is hereby authorized to engage, retain and compensate special counsel for the defense of all such actions described in subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1967, § 2-16)
Secs. 2-361-2-365. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PURCHASING SYSTEM 

Sec. 2-366. - Authority of city clerk to prescribe and maintain forms and procedures. 
    The city clerk may prescribe and maintain such forms and procedures as necessary to expedite purchasing by the city. 
(Ord. No. 5670, § 1(13-132), 2-17-81)
Sec. 2-367. - General purchasing procedure. 
    The quantitative criteria for determining the degree of formality to be observed for each particular purchase by the city shall be as follows: 
(1)	Purchases under one thousand dollars. Budgeted purchases under one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) may be made directly by the department heads without formality. 
(2)	Purchases from one thousand dollars to two thousand five hundred dollars. For budgeted purchases from one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) to two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00), the city administrator or department heads, without council approval, shall solicit at least three (3) bids, either in writing, by telephone, or both. The execution of the bid requirement should be documented on a prescribed form, which form shall include a statement from the finance director that the budgeted funds are available for immediate disbursement. The bids shall be submitted to the city council for subsequent award of the contract of services to the lowest responsible bidder who submits a responsive bid which is most advantageous to the city (hereafter referred to as the "lowest responsible bidder"). 
(3)	Purchases over two thousand five hundred dollars. Whenever any contemplated purchase or contract for services is for more than two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00), the city council, by motion, or the city administrator shall direct the city clerk to solicit at least three (3) written sealed bids for the items or services. The city council shall award the purchase or contract of services to the lowest responsible bidder. 
(4)	Solicitation of bids. Whenever any contemplated purchase or contract for services requires solicitation for bids, the city clerk, upon request of the city administrator, a department head or by order of the city council, shall cause to be published in no less than one (1) issue of a newspaper of general circulation in the city a notice inviting bids. The first such notice shall be published at least seven (7) days prior to the date set for the receipt of the bids. Such notice shall include a general description of the repairs or improvements and the time and place for opening bids. In addition, the city clerk shall post a notice inviting bids in the city administrator offices and may mail to all responsible prospective contractors for services performed a copy of the notice inserted in the newspaper as required in this subsection. This provision shall not apply to those cases in which bids are solicited by telephone as set forth in subsection (2) hereof. 
(5)	Notwithstanding any provision of this Article V, bids may be opened and reviewed in public by a council committee, or by the city administrator, city clerk, and department head meeting together, and subsequently reported to the council for its consideration and award. 
(6)	Notwithstanding any provision of this article, the city administrator may, with council approval, extend any contract for purchases or services awarded hereunder for the same or similar purchases or services by no more than fifty (50) percent of the original contract amount. 
(Ord. No. 5670, § 1(13-133), 2-17-81; Ord. No. 6012, § 1, 8-6-84; Ord. No. 6181, § 1, 7-21-86; Ord. No. 6676, § 11, 2-1-93) 
Sec. 2-368. - Authority to apply more formal procedures; criteria for selection of lowest responsible bidder. 
(a)	A department head or the city council shall not be precluded from applying more formal procedures in a particular situation than those called for under the prescribed requirements. 
(b)	The following criteria for selection of the lowest responsible bidder shall be considered:
(1)	Responsibility of bidder:
a.	The financial stability of the bidder;
b.	The production capability of the bidder;
c.	The ability of the bidder to deliver or perform on a timely basis;
d.	The quality of past performance on contracts or services;
e.	The principal place of business of the bidder.
(2)	Responsiveness of bidder:
a.	The conformity of specifications, terms and conditions to those in the invitation of bids; 
b.	The absence of unilateral mistakes or obvious errors made in calculating or presenting figures; 
c.	The reasonableness of price.
(Ord. No. 5670, § 1(13-134), 2-17-81)
Sec. 2-369. - Exceptions to general procedure. 
    Notwithstanding the provisions of section 2-467, purchases of items or services pursuant to this division may be made which are not in conformity with section 2-367 under the following circumstances: 
(1)	Single source purchases. If there is only one acceptable vendor capable of furnishing a particular service or commodity, the city council or department head may procure such service or commodity without bidding. The purchaser shall document the particular facts which make the item a single source purchase. 
(2)	Emergency purchases. Where an emergency situation requires immediate purchase of supplies or services and time is of the essence, the mayor shall authorize the procurement of the supplies or services needed without bidding. The purchaser shall maintain a written record of the circumstances surrounding emergency purchases. All emergency purchases shall be documented and presented at the next regularly scheduled meeting of the city council. 
(3)	Situations calling for competitive negotiations. Where it can be demonstrated that the city receives the best value on a purchase through informal discussion and bargaining rather than through the conventional bidding process, the purchaser shall not be required to follow the conventional bidding process exclusively. Such purchases should be documented by the purchaser. Examples would include, but not be limited to, circumstances when time is a crucial factor, when the procurement involves high technology items or when there is obvious inherent economy in purchasing from a particular vendor. 
(4)	Cooperative purchasing. Established purchasing procedures should not apply to purchases made by, through or with the division of procurement of the state or any other governmental agency or unit with which the city is permitted to engage in cooperative purchasing. 
(5)	Confidential expenditures. Confidential expenditures, such as payments to informants, purchase of materials as evidence (such as narcotics) or other uses as may be required by law enforcement personnel working in an undercover capacity, cannot be subject to normal purchasing procedures. At such time as the circumstances require such expenditures to be made by the city, an imprest cash fund controlled by a bonded officer of the city should be established. All disbursements made from such fund should be approved by the chief of police and should be documented by written vouchers showing date, amount, nature of expenditure, signature of requesting officer or agent and approval of the chief of police. 
(6)	Professional services. Except by order of the city council, this division shall not apply to the acquisition of services of auditors, accountants, surveyors, registered professional engineers, land planners, consultants to the mayor and city council and attorneys-at-law providing legal services to the city and city employees and officers, both temporary and permanent. 
(Ord. No. 5670, § 1(13-135), 2-17-81)
Sec. 2-370. - Blanket purchase orders; purchase orders for recurring operating items or supplies. 
    Blanket authority not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) may be authorized by the mayor to facilitate purchasing items on credit from local business. 
(Ord. No. 5670, § 1(13-136), 2-17-81; Ord. No. 6676, § 21, 2-1-93)
Sec. 2-371. - Rules and regulations. 
    The mayor and a majority of the city councilmen are hereby authorized to promulgate rules and regulations to carry out the purposes of this division. 
(Ord. No. 5670, § 1(13-137), 2-17-81)
Sec. 2-372. - Division inapplicable to purchases of real estate, easements, etc. 
    Nothing contained in this division shall be construed to govern the purchase or acquisition of real estate, rights-of-way, easements, licenses or any other interest of land or negotiated tap-on agreements. 
(Ord. No. 5670, § 1(13-138), 2-17-81)
Sec. 2-373. - Authority to reject bids. 
    Notwithstanding any provision of Division 4, the city may, without cause, reject any or all bids. 
(Ord. No. 6678, § 4, 2-16-93)
Chapter 3 - AIRPORT AND AIRCRAFT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note-Section 1 of Ord. No. 5988, adopted May 21, 1984, repealed §§ 3-1-3-5 of the 1967 Code as amended by Ord. No. 5772, § 1, adopted Feb. 1, 1982, from which §§ 3-11-3-15, the substantive provisions of Ch. 3, were derived. Said chapter formerly contained provisions relative to the municipal airport. Section 2 of Ord. No. 5988 enacted a new Ch. 3 to read as herein set forth.
State Law reference- Aircraft and airports, RSMo Ch. 305; authority of city to operate, maintain, regulate airports, RSMo 305.170.

Sec. 3-1. - Control of municipal airport. 
    The general control of the city airport shall be under the supervision of the director of the department of municipal services. 
(Ord. No. 5988, § 2, 5-21-84)
Sec. 3-2. - Insurance required for commercial operators. 
    All commercial operators of aircraft at the municipal airport shall carry bodily injury liability insurance and property damage insurance with a minimum of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00). 
(Ord. No. 5988, § 2, 5-21-84)
Sec. 3-3. - Location of hangar space. 
    The general control of all locations of hangar space shall be under the control of the director of the department of municipal services. 
(Ord. No. 5988, § 2, 5-21-84)
Sec. 3-4. - Unlawful to enter upon runways, enclosures; exceptions. 
(a)	No person shall enter onto any of the runways of the municipal airport of the city, nor into the enclosure surrounding the runways, other than personnel of and passengers in aircraft landing at or which are parked at the airport, and persons authorized by the mayor or a councilman of the city. 
(b)	Nothing contained in this section shall prohibit the entrance onto the premises by:
(1)	Any duly authorized representative of the federal aviation administration.
(2)	The chief of police or the fire chief or any member of the police department or fire department of the city while in the discharge of their duties. 
(3)	Any lessee of any property which is a part of the property described in this section.
(4)	Any person meeting other persons landing at the airport or accompanying persons who are departing therefrom. 
(5)	Personnel present and necessary for maintenance of aircraft.
(Ord. No. 5988, § 2, 5-21-84)
Sec. 3-5. - Vehicles prohibited from landing area; exception. 
    All land motor vehicles shall be prohibited from the landing area of the municipal memorial airport except those vehicles marked with red flags. 
(Ord. No. 5988, § 2, 5-21-84)
Sec. 3-6. - Duties of director regarding airport. 
    The director of the department of municipal services, acting pursuant to the guidance and under the control of the council municipal services committee shall have the following duties: 
(a)	To develop and recommend rules and regulations applicable to airport activity within the confines of existing federal, state, county and city laws or ordinances, and recommend additional laws or ordinances or revisions thereto. 
(b)	To represent the city in all matters dealing with air traffic and commerce.
(c)	To receive and screen all applications for catering services, fuel, oil, transportation, fixed-based operations, flight instructions, manufacturing or such other activities involving the municipal airport and make recommendations to the mayor or city council as applicable. 
(d)	To investigate the need for and recommend action necessary for maintenance of the municipal airport so long as such airport requires city labor, equipment and materials or the contribution of labor, equipment and materials by others. 
(e)	To develop and update through the assistance of suitable technical consultants a master airport or improvement program, including but not restricted to, runways, lighting, taxiways, parking area, hangars, restaurants, lodging, communications, servicing, navigations, and flight aides. 
(f)	To develop and recommend ways and means for the accomplishment to an approved master airport plan. 
(Ord. No. 5988, § 2, 5-21-84)
Sec. 3-7. - Airport representative. 
    At the first regular meeting of the city council in May of each year, or as soon thereafter as practicable, the mayor shall appoint one member of the municipal services committee as the airport representative. 
(Ord. No. 5988, § 2, 5-21-84)
Sec. 3-8. - Airport tenants' representative. 
    The airport tenants, as of April 1 of each year, shall select a person to represent their interests on airport matters before the municipal services committee. 
(Ord. No. 5988, § 2, 5-21-84)
Chapter 4 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages prohibited in massage establishments, § 15-12; alcoholic beverages in city park, § 19-5; license taxes for alcoholic beverages, § 28-24(2); driving while under the influence of intoxicants, § 29-73; prima facie driving while intoxicated, § 29-74.
State Law reference- Liquor control law, RSMo Ch. 311; nonintoxicating beer, RSMo Ch. 312.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 4-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
    Intoxicating liquor shall mean and include alcohol for beverage purposes, alcoholic, spirituous, vinous, fermented, malt or other liquors, or combination of liquors, a part of which is spirituous, vinous or fermented, and all preparations or mixtures for beverage purposes, containing in excess of three and two-tenths (3.2) percent of alcohol by weight. 
    Nonintoxicating beer shall mean any beer manufactured from pure hops, and pure barley malt or other wholesome grains or cereals, and wholesome yeast, and pure water, and free from all harmful substances, preservatives and adulterants, and having an alcoholic content of more than one-half of one percent by volume and not exceeding three and two-tenths (3.2) percent by weight. 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 311.020, 312.010. 
Sec. 4-2. - Drinking in public prohibited. 
    No person shall consume or drink any nonintoxicating beer or any intoxicating liquor of any kind in or upon any public street, sidewalk or other public place, except as provided in section 19-5 relating to picnic areas of public parks. 
(Code 1967, § 20-7.2)
Sec. 4-3. - Sale or handling by minors. 
(a)	Except as provided in subsections (b) and (c) of this section, no person under the age of twenty-one (21) years shall sell or assist in the sale or dispensing of intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer. 
(b)	In any place of business licensed in accordance with this chapter, where at least fifty (50) percent of the gross sales made consists of goods, merchandise or commodities other than intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer in the original package, persons at least eighteen (18) years of age may stock, arrange displays, accept payment for and sack for carryout intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer. Delivery of intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer away from the licensed business premises cannot be performed by anyone under the age of twenty-one (21) years. 
(c)	In any distillery, warehouse, wholesale distributorship or similar place of business which stores or distributes intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer but which does not sell intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer at retail, persons at least eighteen (18) years of age may be employed and their duties may include the handling of intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer for all purposes except consumption, sale at retail, or dispensing for consumption or sale at retail. 
(d)	Persons eighteen (18) years of age or older may, when acting in the capacity as a waiter or waitress, accept payment for or serve intoxicating liquor in places of business which sell food for consumption on the premises if at least fifty (50) percent of all sales in those places consists of food; provided that nothing in this section shall authorize persons under twenty-one (21) years of age to mix or serve across the bar intoxicating beverages. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 311.300. 
Sec. 4-4. - Dancing restricted on licensed premises. 
    Any person licensed under the provisions of this chapter who employs an entertainer or performer, or permits any entertainer, performer or patron to perform a dance of any kind whatever upon the bar or any other place used for serving food or beverages, or in any place within the premises open to view from the sidewalk or street, or allows such dance to be performed other than on a raised dias or platform or some designated area adequately set aside from the immediate vicinity where patrons may be seated or standing shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1967, § 4-31)
Cross reference- Amusements generally, Ch. 5. 
Secs. 4-5-4-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - NONINTOXICATING BEER[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Regulation of nonintoxicating beer, RSMo Ch. 312.

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 4-16. - Breaking of original package. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person holding a permit authorizing the sale of nonintoxicating beer in the original package to allow such original package to be broken, or to allow any of such nonintoxicating beer to be consumed, in or upon the premises described in such permit. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 312.390. 
Sec. 4-17. - Misrepresentation of age. 
(a)	Any person of the age of seventeen (17) years and under the age of twenty-one (21) years who represents that he has attained the age of twenty-one (21) for the purpose of purchasing, asking for or in any way receiving nonintoxicating beer, shall, upon conviction be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(b)	Any person under the age of seventeen (17) years who represents that he has attained the age of twenty-one (21) years for the purpose of purchasing, asking for or in any way receiving nonintoxicating beer, shall be dealt with in accordance with RSMo Ch. 211. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 312.405. 
Sec. 4-18. - Purchase or possession by minor. 
    Any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years, who purchases or attempts to purchase, or has in his possession, any nonintoxicating beer is guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1967, § 4-5)
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 312.407. 
Sec. 4-19. - Supplying to certain persons prohibited. 
    No person or his employee shall sell or supply nonintoxicating beer or permit the same to be sold or supplied to any person who is under or apparently under the influence of alcoholic beverages. Nonintoxicating beer shall not be given, sold or otherwise supplied to any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years, but this shall not apply to the supplying of nonintoxicating beer to a person under such age for medicinal purposes only, or by the parent or guardian of such person or to the administering of such nonintoxicating beer to such person by a physician. 
(Code 1967, § 4-3)
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 312.400. 
Sec. 4-20. - Sales prohibited between certain hours. 
    No person having a license under the provisions of this article shall sell, give away or otherwise dispose of, or suffer the same to be done, upon or about his premises any nonintoxicating beer in any quantity between the hours of 1:30 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. and any person violating any provisions of this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by imprisonment in the county jail for a term of not more than one year, or by a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than four hundred dollars ($400.00) or by both such fine and jail sentence. 
(Code 1967, § 4-2)
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 312.410. 
Secs. 4-21-4-25. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Occupational license taxes generally, § 28-11 et seq.
State Law reference- Licensing authority for nonintoxicating beer, RSMo 312.140.

Sec. 4-26. - Required; separate license for consumption on premises. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or expose for sale in this city nonintoxicating beer in any quantity without taking out a license from the city. A separate license shall be taken out for the sale of nonintoxicating beer for consumption on the premises where sold. 
(Code 1967, § 4-19)
State Law reference- Permit necessary, RSMo 312.030. 
Sec. 4-27. - Application. 
    An application for a license to sell nonintoxicating beer under the provisions of this division shall be filed with the city clerk and shall be on forms to be furnished by the clerk and signed and sworn to by the applicant. 
(Code 1967, § 4-20)
State Law reference- Application for state license, RSMo 312.080. 
Sec. 4-28. - Qualifications of licensee. 
    No person shall be granted a license under this division unless such person is of good moral character and a qualified legal voter and taxpaying citizen of the state; and no person shall be granted a license or permit hereunder whose license as such dealer has been revoked, or who has been convicted since the ratification of the twenty-first amendment to the Constitution of the United States, of the violations of the provisions of any law applicable to the manufacture or sale of intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer, or who employs or has employed in his business, as such dealer, any person whose license has been revoked or who has been convicted of violating the provisions of any such law since the date aforesaid. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions for state license, RSMo 312.040. 
Sec. 4-29. - Separate license for each place of business; contents. 
    A separate license shall be required under this division for each place of business. Every license issued under the provisions of this division shall particularly describe the premises at which nonintoxicating beer may be sold thereunder, and such license shall not be deemed to authorize or permit the sale of nonintoxicating beer at any place other than that described therein. 
(Code 1967, § 4-21)
State Law reference- Similar provisions for state license, RSMo 312.110. 
Sec. 4-30. - Approval; issuance to owner, proprietor or keeper only. 
    Upon the filing of an application for a license under this division, such application shall be presented to the city council at its next regular or special meeting, and, upon approval of such application by a majority of the city council, and upon payment of the license tax provided for in section 4-31, the city clerk shall issue a license to the applicant to conduct business in the city. 
(Code 1967, § 4-21)
Sec. 4-31. - Fees. 
    Before any license shall be issued for the manufacture or sale of nonintoxicating beer in the city, the applicant therefor shall pay to the city a fee as follows: 
(1)	For the manufacture, and the sale by the manufacturer, of nonintoxicating beer brewed or manufactured in this state .....$375.00 
(2)	For the sale by any distributor or wholesaler, other than the manufacturer or brewer thereof .....50.00 
(3)	For the sale for consumption on the premises where sold .....35.00 
(4)	For the sale by grocers and other merchants and dealers in the original package direct to consumers, but not for resale .....22.50 
(5)	For sale to duly licensed wholesalers and soliciting orders for the sale .....75.00 
(Code 1967, § 4-22)
State Law reference- Amount of state fees, RSMo 312.100; amount charged by city regulated, RSMo 312.140. 
Sec. 4-32. - Term; proration of fees. 
    The annual licenses issued under this division shall be dated July first, and shall expire June thirtieth of the following year, and the fees for such licenses shall be paid annually in advance. Licenses may be issued for part of a year for businesses commenced after July first, and proportionate fees charged based on the months or fraction of a month such licenses are to run to the next June thirtieth following. 
(Code 1967, § 4-23)
State Law reference- Similar provisions for state licenses, RSMo 312.110. 
Sec. 4-33. - Posting on premises required. 
    All licenses issued pursuant to the provisions of this division shall be kept conspicuously posted in the place for which such licenses were issued. 
Sec. 4-34. - Licensee not to sell intoxicating liquor. 
    No person having a license under the provisions of this division to sell nonintoxicating beer at retail shall be granted or permitted to hold a license to sell malt liquor containing alcohol in excess of three and two-tenths (3.2) percent by weight or any other kind of intoxicating liquor; nor shall any person be granted or permitted to hold a license to sell nonintoxicating beer in, upon or about the premises of any person who is the holder of a license to sell intoxicating liquor. 
(Code 1967, § 4-6)
State Law reference- Similar provisions for state licenses, RSMo 312.050. 
Sec. 4-35. - Transferability. 
    No license issued under this division shall be transferable or assignable. 
(Code 1967, § 4-24)
State Law reference- Similar provisions for state licenses, RSMo 312.130. 
Sec. 4-36. - Revocation; notice and hearing. 
    Whenever it is shown to the city council that a dealer licensed under this division has not at all times kept an orderly place or house, or has violated any of the provisions of this division or of RSMo Ch. 312, or has no license from the state supervisor of liquor control, or has made a false affidavit in his application for a license, the city council, after a hearing thereon, shall revoke the license of such dealer, giving ten (10) days' notice, in writing, thereof prior to the hearing thereon to the dealer, or any person in charge of or employed in the place licensed stating the time, place, purpose and grounds therefor, at which hearing the dealer may have counsel and produce witnesses in his behalf. 
(Code 1967, § 4-25)
State Law reference- License revocation, RSMo 312.237. 
Secs. 4-37-4-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - INTOXICATING LIQUOR[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Liquor control law, RSMo Ch. 311.

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 4-46. - Exemptions from article provisions. 
    This article shall not apply to the possession by a druggist of intoxicating liquor purchased by him from a licensed vendor under the Liquor Control Act of the state, or intoxicating liquor lawfully acquired and transported into the state by him pursuant to such act, such liquor to be used in connection with the business of a druggist in compounding medicines or as a solvent or preservative, nor shall this article apply to the sale of intoxicating liquors by druggists on prescription from a regularly licensed physician. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 311.470. 
Sec. 4-47. - Misrepresentation of age by minor. 
    Any person of the age of seventeen (17) years and under the age of twenty-one (21) years who shall represent that he or she has attained the age of twenty-one (21) years for the purpose of purchasing, asking for or in anyway receiving any intoxicating liquor, except in cases authorized by law, shall upon conviction be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. Any person under the age of seventeen (17) years who shall represent that he or she has attained the age of twenty-one (21) years for the purpose of purchasing, asking for or in anyway receiving any intoxicating liquor, except in cases authorized by law, may be considered a delinquent child and may be dealt with in accordance with the provisions of RSMo Ch. 211. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions. RSMo 311.320. 
Sec. 4-48. - Purchase or possession by minor. 
    Any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years, who purchases or attempts to purchase, or has in his possession, any intoxicating liquor is guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1967, § 4-5)
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 311.325. 
Sec. 4-49. - Sale prohibited during certain hours. 
(a)	No person having a license under this article nor any employee of such person shall sell, give away or otherwise dispose or suffer the same to be done upon or about his premises, any intoxicating liquor in any quantity between the hours of 1:30 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on weekdays and between the hours of 1:30 a.m. Sunday and 9:00 a.m. Where such licenses authorizing the sale of intoxicating liquor by the drink are held by clubs or hotels this section shall apply only to the room or rooms in which intoxicating liquor is dispensed; and where such licenses are held by restaurants whose business is conducted in one room only and substantial quantities of food and merchandise, other than intoxicating liquors are dispensed, then the licensee shall keep securely locked during the hours and on the days herein specified all refrigerators, cabinets, cases, boxes and taps from which intoxicating liquor is dispensed. A "closed place" is defined to mean a place where all doors are locked and where no patrons are in the place or about the premises. Any person violating any provision of this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(b)	When December thirty-first falls on Sunday, any person having a license to sell intoxicating liquor by the drink may be open for business and sell intoxicating liquor by the drink under the provisions of his license on that day after 1:00 p.m. and until the time which would be lawful on another day of the week. 
(Code 1067, §§ 4-2, 4-4; Ord. No. 6471, § 1,5-21-90; Ord. No. 6676, § 22, 2-1-93; Ord. No. 6703, § 1, 6-21-93; Ord. No. 7484, § 1, 9-2-03) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 311.290, 311.298. 
Sec. 4-50. - Supplying to certain persons prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or his employee to sell or supply intoxicating liquor or permit same to be sold or supplied to a habitual drunkard or to any person who is under or apparently under the influence of intoxicating liquor. Intoxicating liquor shall not be given, sold or otherwise supplied to any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years. 
(Code 1967, § 4-3)
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 311.310. 
Sec. 4-51. - Window displays prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to display in any street window or show window any intoxicating liquor, or any package, bottle or container bearing the label or brand of any intoxicating liquor. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 311.350. 
Sec. 4-52. - Possession of intoxicating liquor restricted. 
    No person shall possess intoxicating liquor within the city unless the same has been acquired from some person holding a duly authorized license to sell the same under this chapter, or unless the intoxicating liquor is had or kept with the written or printed permission of the state supervisor of liquor control, and the package in which intoxicating liquor is contained and from which it is taken for consumption has, while containing intoxicating liquor, been labeled and sealed with the official seal prescribed under state law and the regulations made thereunder. 
(Code 1967, § 4-7)
State Law reference- Possession of intoxicating liquor, RSMo 311.580(2). 
Secs. 4-53-4-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Occupational license tax generally, § 28-11 et seq.
State Law reference- State license required, RSMo 311.050; licensing authority of the city, RSMo 311.220.

Sec. 4-61. - Required; classes. 
(a)	It shall be unlawful for any person to manufacture, distill, brew, sell or expose for sale in this city, intoxicating liquor in any quantity, without taking out a license from the city. A separate license shall be taken out for each of the following classes of sales of intoxicating liquors in which the licensee desires to engage: 
(1)	Sales of all kinds of intoxicating liquors in the original package not to be consumed on the premises where sold; 
(2)	Sales of malt liquor containing alcohol in excess of three and two-tenths (3.2) percent by weight and not in excess of five (5) percent by weight by grocers and other merchants and dealers for sale in the original package direct to consumers but not for resale and not for consumption on the premises where sold; 
(3)	Sales of malt liquor containing alcohol not in excess of five (5) percent by weight and more than three and two-tenths (3.2) percent by weight and light wines containing alcohol not in excess of fourteen (14) percent by weight made exclusively from grapes, berries and other fruits and vegetables, at retail by the drink, for consumption on the premises where sold, which license shall also permit the holder to sell non-intoxicating beer. 
(4)	Sale of intoxicating liquor of all kinds at retail by the drink for consumption on the premises where sold, including the sale of intoxicating liquors in the original package. 
(5)	Sunday restaurant-Bar by the drink. For the retail sale of intoxicating liquor in excess of five percent (5%) of alcohol by weight between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and midnight on Sunday at retail for consumption on the premises where sold, and the premises is a restaurant bar as defined in RSMo 311.097, as amended. 
(6)	Picnic retail liquor by the drink. For issuance of a temporary license to certain not-for-profit organizations, as authorized in Section 311.482 RSMo, as amended, for the retail sale of intoxicating liquor by the drink for consumption on premises where sold at picnics and similar gatherings for a period not to exceed seven days in any fiscal period. If the event will be held on a Sunday, the permit shall authorize the sale of intoxicating liquor on that day beginning at 11:00 a.m. 
(7)	Caterers' retail liquor by the drink. For issuance of a license to caterers and other persons who provide provisions and services at a particular function, occasion or event at a particular location for a period not to exceed one hundred twenty (120) consecutive hours, allowing the temporary sale of retail liquor by the drink, all as authorized in Section 311.200 RSMo, as amended. 
(8)	Caterers' retail five (5) percent beer-wine by the drink. For issuance of a license to caterers and other persons who provide provisions and services at a particular function, occasion or event at a particular location for a period not to exceed one hundred twenty (120) consecutive hours, allowing the temporary sale of retail five (5) percent beer-wine by the drink, all as authorized in Chapter 311, RSMo., as amended. 
(9)	Picnic retail five (5) percent beer-wine by the drink. For issuance of a temporary license to certain not-for-profit organizations for the retail sale of five (5) percent beer by the drink at picnics and similar gatherings for a period not to exceed seven (7) days in any fiscal period, all as authorized in Chapter 311, RSMo., as amended. 
(b)	Each license shall apply to the class for which issued, and it shall be unlawful to sell or expose for sale any intoxicating liquor except in the manner authorized in the license held by the licensee as issued under this division. 
(Code 1967, § 4.19; Ord. No. 7536, § 1, 4-19-04; Ord. No. 7906, § 1, 10-5-09; Ord. No. 8110, § 1, 4-15-2013) 
Sec. 4-62. - Application. 
    Application for a license to sell intoxicating liquors under the provisions of this division shall be filed with the city clerk and shall be on forms to be furnished by the clerk and signed and sworn to by the applicant. 
(Code 1967, § 4-20)
Sec. 4-63. - Qualifications of licensee. 
    No person shall be issued a license under this division unless such person is of good moral character and a qualified legal voter and taxpaying citizen of the state; and no person shall be issued a license or permit hereunder whose license as such dealer has been revoked, or who has been convicted, since the ratification of the twenty-first amendment to the Constitution of the United States, of the violations of the provisions of any law applicable to the manufacture or sale of intoxicating liquor, or who employs or has employed in his business, as such dealer, any person whose license has been revoked or who has been convicted of violating the provisions of any such law since the date aforesaid. 
(Code 1967, § 4.27)
State Law reference- Similar provisions for state licenses, RSMo 311.060. 
Sec. 4-64. - Distance restrictions from churches, schools. 
    No license shall be issued for the sale of intoxicating liquor within one hundred (100) feet of any school, church or other building regularly used as a place of religious worship, unless the applicant for the license shall first obtain the consent in writing of the board of directors of the school, or the consent in writing of the majority of the managing board of the church or place of worship; except that when a school, church or place of worship shall hereafter be established within one hundred (100) feet of any place of business licensed to sell intoxicating liquor, the license shall not be denied for lack of consent in writing as herein provided. The distance shall be measured by direct measurement in a horizontal plane on a straight line by means of a steel tape of standard length; and the distance shall be measured between and defined as the distance between the most adjacent point on the property lines of any church or school of learning and the most adjacent point on the frontal line or street line property line of the building in question. 
(Code 1967, § 4-28; Ord. No. 5763, § 1, 6-15-81)
State Law reference- Sale prohibited near schools, churches, RSMo 311.080. 
Sec. 4-65. - Separate license required for each place of business; contents. 
    A separate license shall be required under this division for each place of business. Every license issued under the provisions of this division shall particularly describe the premises at which intoxicating liquor may be sold thereunder, and such license shall not be deemed to authorize or permit the sale of intoxicating liquor at any place other than that described therein. 
(Code 1967, § 4-21)
Sec. 4-66. - Fees. 
    Before any license shall be issued for the manufacture or sale of intoxicating liquors in the city, the applicant therefor shall pay to the city a fee as follows: 
(1)	For the manufacturing, brewing, distilling or blending of intoxicating liquors:
a.	Containing not more than five (5) percent of alcohol by weight .....$300.00 
b.	Containing not more than twenty-two (22) percent of alcohol by weight .....150.00 
c.	Of all kinds .....300.00 
(2)	For selling to duly licensed wholesalers and soliciting orders for the sale by or through a duly licensed wholesaler of intoxicating liquors: 
a.	Containing not more than five (5) percent of alcohol by weight .....75.00 
b.	Containing not more than twenty-two (22) percent of alcohol by weight .....150.00 
c.	Of all kinds .....375.00 
(3)	For the sale by a wholesaler to a person duly licensed to sell, at retail, intoxicating liquor: 
a.	Containing not more than five (5) percent of alcohol by weight .....75.00 
b.	Containing not more than twenty-two (22) percent of alcohol by weight .....150.00 
c.	Of all kinds .....375.00 
(4)	For the manufacture in quantities not exceeding seventy-five thousand (75,000) gallons of light wines containing not more than fourteen (14) percent of alcohol by weight exclusively from grapes, berries and other fruits and vegetables grown in the state, for each five hundred (500) gallons or fraction thereof .....7.50 
    A manufacturer hereunder may sell directly to the consumer at the winery in lots not exceeding five (5) gallons, and to duly licensed wholesalers and retailers in lots of five (5) gallons or more. 
(5)	For the sale at retail of intoxicating liquors in connection with a drugstore, a cigar and tobacco store, a general merchandise store, a confectionery or delicatessen, or a store having and keeping a stock of goods valuing at least one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), exclusive of fixtures and intoxicating liquors .....75.00 
(6)	For the sale of malt liquor by grocers and other merchants and dealers in the original package direct to consumers, but not for resale (includes Sunday sales) .....150.00 
    This license shall also permit the sale of non-intoxicating beer in the original package direct to consumers, but not for resale. 
(7)	For the sale of malt liquor by the drink for consumption on the premises where sold (includes Sunday sales) .....75.00 
    This license shall also permit the sale of non-intoxicating beer by the drink for consumption on the premises where sold. 
(8)	For the sale of malt liquor and light wines by the drink for consumption on the premises where sold .....75.00 
    This license shall also permit the sale of non-intoxicating beer by the drink for consumption on the premises where sold. 
(9)	For the sale of intoxicating liquor, by the drink for consumption on the premises where sold .....450.00 
    This license shall also permit the sale of intoxicating liquor in the original package. 
(10)	For a restaurant bar licensed under RSMo. §311.215 .....300.00 
(11)	For the sale of intoxicating liquor in the original package on Sunday .....300.00 
(12)	For the sale of intoxicating liquor by the drink, on Sunday, for consumption on the premises where sold .....150.00 
(13)	For the retail sale of intoxicating liquor by the drink by certain not-for-profit organizations for consumption on premises where sold at picnics and similar gatherings .....37.50 
(14)	For temporary sale of retail liquor by the drink to caterers and other persons for an event at a particular location for a period not to exceed one hundred twenty (120) consecutive hours, for each 24-hour period, or part thereof .....15.00 
(15)	For temporary sale of retail beer-wine by the drink by caterers and other persons for an event at a particular location for a period not to exceed one hundred twenty (120) consecutive hours for each 24-hour period or part thereof .....15.00 
(16)	For picnic sale of retail beer-wine by the drink by certain not-for-profit organizations at picnics and similar gatherings for a period not to exceed seven (7) days in any fiscal period .....37.50 
(Code 1967, § 4-29; Ord. No. 6057, § 16, 2-4-85; Ord. No. 6703, § 2, 6-21-93; Ord. No. 7536, § 2, 4-19-04; Ord. No. 7624, § 1, 6-6-05; Ord. No. 7906, §§ 2.3, 10-5-09; Ord. No. 8110, § 2, 4-15-13) 
State Law reference- Amount of state fees, RSMo 311.180-311.200; amount charged by city regulated, RSMo 311,220. 
Sec. 4-67. - Term. 
    Each license issued under this division may be issued for a period of six (6) months or one (1) year, as applied for. 
(Code 1967, § 4-23)
State Law reference- Similar provisions for state licenses, RSMo 311.240. 
Sec. 4-68. - Display. 
    All licenses issued pursuant to the provisions of this division shall be kept conspicuously posted in the place for which such license was issued. 
Sec. 4-69. - Transferability. 
(a)	No license issued under this division shall be transferable or assignable except as provided in this section. 
(b)	In the event of the death of the licensee, the widow or widower or the next of kin of such deceased licensee, who shall meet the other requirements of this division may make application for a transfer of such license to permit the operation of the business of the deceased for the remainder of the period for which a license fee has been paid by the deceased. 
(c)	Whenever one or more members of a partnership withdraws from the partnership, the remaining partners may be permitted to continue to operate for the remainder of the period for which the license fee has been paid, without obtaining a new license. 
State Law reference- Licenses nontransferable; exceptions, RSMo 311.250. 
Sec. 4-70. - Revocation; notice and hearing. 
    Whenever it is shown to the city council that a dealer licensed under this division has not at all times kept an orderly place or house, or has violated any of the provisions of this division or of the Liquor Control Act of the state, or has no license from the state supervisor of liquor control, or has made a false affidavit in his application for a license, the city council, after a hearing thereon, shall revoke the license of such dealer, giving ten (10) days' notice, in writing, thereof prior to the hearing thereon to the dealer, or any person in charge of or employed in the place licensed stating the time, place, purpose and grounds therefor, at which hearing the dealer may have counsel and produce witness in his behalf. 
(Code 1967, § 4-25)
Chapter 5 - AMUSEMENTS[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference- Dancing restricted on licensed alcoholic beverage premises, § 4-4; license tax for billiard hall, § 28-24(13); license tax for bowling alleys, § 28-24(15); license tax for carnivals, § 28-24(19); license tax for circuses, § 28-24(20); license tax for dance halls, § 28-24(23); license tax for equestrian performances, § 28-24(26); license tax for menageries, § 28-24(51); license taxes for opera houses, § 28-24(52); license tax for moving pictures, § 28-24(57); license tax for music boxes, § 28-24(58); license tax for pinball machines, § 28-24(65); license tax for pistol gallery, § 28-24(66); license tax for pool halls, § 28-24(67); license tax for shooting gallery, § 28-24(74); license tax for shows, exhibitions, performances and displays, § 28-24(75); license tax for sideshows, § 28-24(76); license tax for skating rink, § 28-24(77); license tax for ten pin alleys, § 28-24(82); license tax for tent shows and stock companies, § 28-24(83); license tax for theatrical performances, § 28-24(84).
